PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to Mr Keating's letter to Caucus dated 10 November in which he attacks the Premiers' tax sharing proposals and the attached copy of what he describes as the `final States' proposal' annotated by Mr Keating. I ask the Minister whether he accepts Mr Keating's alternative proposal, which he puts in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Offer the States a guaranteed real increase in financial assistance grants on a triennium basis. At the same time we could free up more of the tied grants we currently provide.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my practice or function to comment on a letter from a backbencher which was sent to some people. So I do not propose to do so. Let me say in relation to the Premiers Conference, it is still hoped that—
—Off again, on again.

—Yes. It is still hoped that we can continue the Special Premiers Conference process. It makes sense for that process to continue because there is much to gain from it. I hope that will be the result of further discussions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of the Minister's answer in which he prefers not to comment, can I therefore ask him whether Mr Hawke—who has now accepted Mr Keating's interpretation of the Premiers' tax sharing proposals—has now accepted Mr Keating's advice on the alternative proposal the Commonwealth should put, and has, in fact, Mr Hawke already raised that issue with the Premiers?

—I have no information on that. When I was answering questions here a day or two ago, I said that the Commonwealth position would be refined and put to the Premiers at the Special Premiers Conference. In spite of the eagerness of the Opposition to find out what that position was, that answer remains as valid today as when I gave it two or three days ago. If the Premiers Conference is to proceed, then that answer remains again: the Commonwealth position will be refined and put to the Premiers at the appropriate time.
—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise on progress with the environmental impact statement for the proposed third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport?

—Minister Kelly provided me with her Department's report on the EIS this morning, with a letter containing her recommendations. I now propose to take a submission on the third runway to Cabinet tomorrow for a decision by Cabinet, which will be followed by a meeting of the Parliamentary Labor Party to discuss the issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to statements by the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, at an ALP business breakfast in Brisbane on 27 August:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government is fully committed to handing substantial taxing powers back to the States.
I ask: does the Government still hold this view?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing to add to the answer that I gave to Senator Hill on the preparation of the Commonwealth's position for the Premiers Conference.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to the call for intervention and assistance from the world powers by the Croatians caught in the battle against Yugoslav forces in Zagreb and Dubrovnik. Could the Minister inform the Senate what action the United Nations has taken towards obtaining a peaceful settlement of this war? Is the International Red Cross assisting with care of the sick and wounded in Zagreb and Dubrovnik? What access to information do Australian-Croatian families have about relatives living in Zagreb and Dubrovnik?

—I answered a question on this issue from Senator Hill yesterday, but Senator Jones's question takes the matter somewhat further and into a more specific area. As I said to Senator Hill yesterday, the international community is working towards a peaceful solution in Yugoslavia, and the European Community has now decided to impose economic measures against Yugoslavia.

PARA.TAB: But the point of Senator Jones's question goes more to the suffering of particular communities and individuals in Yugoslavia. The International Red Cross has been heavily involved in helping the victims of the conflict. The International Red Cross has some 40 delegates in all of the major conflict areas in Yugoslavia. For example, the International Red Cross has been assisting the people of Dubrovnik as best it can, with parcels being sent to its local branch; it is intended to allow a relief vessel loaded with supplies into Dubrovnik in the next couple of days; and stocks of emergency medical supplies have been maintained at various centres throughout the country for distribution to hospitals.

With regard to Australians with families in Croatia and other parts of Yugoslavia, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade made a major effort to register with the Australian Embassy in Belgrade as many Australian citizens as possible residing in Yugoslavia. The number of registrations increased from about 50 before the crisis to about 6,000 now. Most of these people are dual nationals. About 167 registered Australians live in Zagreb and 19 in Dubrovnik. In most cases where the Department received inquiries about a relative who is an Australian citizen, contact was made and the information passed on to the family in Australia. Where the Embassy has not been able to make phone contact, it has had some success in making contact by telegram. Contact with Zagreb, even if somewhat roundabout, would still seem to be possible. In the one case where the Embassy has been trying to make contact with Dubrovnik, it has so far not succeeded. Where the relatives are not Australians, the Red Cross has been able to offer its assistance.

The Department, through its posts and through the International Red Cross, is continuing its efforts to improve the information flow about particular dual nationals in Dubrovnik, Zagreb and elsewhere and to help in one way or another, and that will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Do Australian Government guidelines exist for Australian business investment in Burma and, if so, what are they? If not, in view of the appalling human rights record of the illegal military regime in Burma, including the continued incarceration of leaders of the elected Government, such as Nobel Peace Laureate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, will the Minister consider drawing up guidelines for Australian business investment in Burma as soon as possible.

—The Australian Government has taken action to ensure that no Australian exports of defence related goods are sent to Burma. It is also currently advocating an international arms embargo against Burma. However, apart from military related investments or exports, the Government has not issued any official guidelines relating to trade or investment in Burma.

PARA.TAB: There are several reasons for that. Whether Australian companies wish to engage in commercial relationships with Burma is essentially a matter for the judgment of the companies. The fact is that Australian companies are not very active in Burma at all because of the abysmal record of the regime there. Its economic performance is not much better than its political record. Australia's trade and investment with Burma is very small and narrowly based.

With regard to the third part of the question, in view of the small value of Australian investment and exports to Burma and the very restrictive foreign investment climate in that country, the formulation of investment guidelines has not been pursued by the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of the Chairman, Mr Tony Steel, and members of the New Zealand Parliamentary Select Committee on Education and Science. The Committee is in Canberra to meet with its counterpart committees in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, with Ministers and education and science authorities. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming them to the Senate, and I trust that their visit will be both educational and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What action is the Government planning to take on calls for a royal commission into organised crime now that the coroner has returned an open finding on the murder of Assistant Commissioner Colin Winchester?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the coroner, Mr Ron Cahill, found that Assistant Commissioner Winchester was murdered but that the finding remains open as to who was responsible for the murder. I am sure that all honourable senators have followed with interest the inquest into that tragic assassination. It is the case that back in May 1990, I think in reply to questions from Senator Durack and Senator Hill, I indicated that if, at the end of Mr Cahill's inquiry, there were issues remaining or new issues came to light, they would be investigated and that if in our view that required a royal commission, that is what we should have. Certainly that has been the Government's attitude.

PARA.TAB: Although I have not yet had a chance to look at the vast amount of evidence evaluated by Mr Cahill in a very exhaustive process and a very comprehensive report, he does say—and I attach great weight to his saying—in his executive summary:

ANSWER.PARA: For my part, given the passing of time and the quality of the witnesses who make allegations of corruption, I cannot foresee a great deal of progress being made by any royal commission or inquiry.

He did say that the question remained for the judgment of others, and that is true. I attach great weight to that observation by the coroner. I believe that it indicates that his findings, which have been so comprehensive and have been reached after such an exhaustive process, need to be given very considerable significance in any Government decision.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to note that over the time the inquest has been undertaken the National Crime Authority has taken a particular interest in the question of organised criminal activity among those few members of the Italian community who have a criminal propensity. In that regard, the National Crime Authority organised a conference in Canberra in November last year attended by various agencies, including from overseas the United States and in particular a delegation of Italian criminal justice agencies. Judge Falcone, who was then inquiring into the mafia in Sicily and who is now based in Rome—I had the pleasure of meeting him both here in Canberra and in Rome—was a very important figure in those consultations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A courageous man.

—A very courageous man, as my colleague says. At its conclusion, that conference resolved to consolidate all relevant information from all agencies in Australia in one database; to ensure the provision to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence of all relevant current information; and to establish with respect to the national database appropriate intelligence analysis. I believe that has formed the basis for a very comprehensive examination of this type of criminal activity that is a phenomenon here in Australia. The report of that conference will be discussed at the National Crime Authority's operational intelligence dissemination conference to be held in Canberra later this month.

PARA.TAB: I believe that under Mr Justice Phillips, who has now been appointed as Chief Justice of the Victorian Supreme Court and, unfortunately, will have to leave his chairmanship of the National Crime Authority, there has been a very cooperative, collaborative attitude taken by all law enforcement agencies in Australia in relation to the question of organised crime in this country. I believe that they are well positioned to carry through with investigations. That will also be a matter which the Government will take into account and give great weight to in deciding whether it will respond to the calls for a royal commission which are associated with this tragic assassination of Assistant Commissioner Winchester.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the Minister assure the Australian people that, in his role as Leader of the Government in the Senate and the representative of the Prime Minister in this place, Mr Hawke has his loyalty, support and, if needed, vote in his objective to remain as leader of the Australian Labor Party up to the next Federal election?

—I answered this question in similar form yesterday. I am not going to have my privacy invaded by being asked how I am going to vote at the next Federal election or in any other election. I confirm my loyalty to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's answer raises a serious supplementary question in that it follows three days in the Senate in which Senator Button has refused to give any sort of clear, unequivocal statement of support for the Prime Minister, rather than the prime ministership. We made that distinction yesterday when, by way of description, Senator Button did what he has just done—basically wasted everyone's time with word plays.
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his supplementary question.
—I ask the Minister: if he cannot offer the Prime Minister his unequivocal, personal loyalty in a meaningful way, does he think he has an obligation to resign from his Government?

—I have no obligation to resign as Leader of the Government in the Senate. I am sometimes tempted because one gets bored if one has no intellectual challenges in this place. One gets bored if one is not inclined to suffer fools gladly—as I am not; I suppose that is a bit of a weakness—and that question seriously arises if I am going to get these idiotic questions from people like Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: I understand Senator Baume's political sensitivities on all these issues. The political problem in Australia at the moment is this: I confess that the majority of the community is not greatly enchanted with this Government at the present time. But I have to say that people are appalled by the prospect of the lot opposite. Everywhere we go in this country we get the same message: `We are a bit angry with you because of high levels of unemployment but, God, do we have to face up to the possibility of even thinking about that other lot?'. That is what we get right across this country.

Senator Baume talks about loyalty to leadership. He has had a pretty chequered record in all of this over the years, and it will continue. One of the problems which people address to me again and again is, `How could we cop that boring Dr Hewson?'. That is a problem which I understand the Opposition is peculiarly sensitive about. Indeed, on the Opposition's own front bench, people are asking that question day after day.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to a recent article in the Adelaide News regarding the high numbers of women without superannuation. The article claims that less than one-quarter of women aged 25 to 64 years have superannuation, compared with 58 per cent of males in the same age group. Could the Minister please explain whether this is correct and whether the measures introduced by the Government in the Budget go any way to remedying the situation?

—The last part of this question asks, `Will the measures introduced in the Budget go part way to remedying this situation?'. In one fell swoop, the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy from 1 July next year will, in fact, remove the inequity that some workers in this society have access to superannuation and many others do not. It will be a quite significant social justice measure by this Government. It will enable these people—most of whom are women—to look forward to retirement with some dignity which, in the absence of superannuation cover, they are now denied. It will be a major social change.

PARA.TAB: I cannot directly corroborate the figures referred to in the Adelaide News; but I can go to the figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It is a fair comment, looking at those figures, to say that there is massive discrimination against women in Australian society. According to the 1990 ABS figures, only 43.8 per cent of working women get superannuation cover in this country compared with 57.5 per cent of working men; 55.7 per cent of women who are full time workers get superannuation cover, but only 25.2 per cent of part time employees who are women get superannuation cover. In the retail section the figures are more alarming, despite the fact that award entitlements to superannuation are a standard in that industry sector. It is also true that thus far only 52 per cent of workers in that industry sector are in receipt of superannuation, despite their legal entitlement to coverage.

The superannuation guarantee levy will remove this gap, remove these inequities and remove the sorry story of the past when only well paid elite and white collar workers got superannuation and if one happened to be a blue collar worker, by and large, one did not. It will ensure 100 per cent coverage of those workers. This will be evidence, of course, of a continuing concern by the Government to improve the status of women in Australian society, to reduce the earning gap between men and women as it now stands and to remove the structural and systematic discrimination women face in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. On 17 October the Minister said he was preparing a statement in answer to my accusations on 9 September, 10 September, 11 September and 17 October that he had misled the Senate in his vicious attack on the most successful Australian company, Robe River Ltd, in that he had made a number of factual errors in relation to that company's industrial relations record. As it is now almost a month later, when will the Minister put down that statement, correct the record and apologise to Robe River and the Senate?

—This is getting to be a boring issue. I have not—and I repeat again for the record for the umpteenth time—misled the Senate. When I do put down a statement it will refute the issues that the honourable senator has raised, which he has pursued consistently despite the fact that they are wrong and that in his persistent—dare I say, militant—pursuit of them, he indeed misleads the Senate himself.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, I have better things to do than spend my days worrying about dealing with Senator Crane's trivial questions. I will put a statement to the Senate when it suits me, which will be fairly soon but not immediately. When I do, Senator Crane will see that it comprehensively answers the question. If Senator Crane is agitated and concerned about this matter, he ought to face up to the challenge I made to him when he last questioned me about this matter. If he conscientiously and seriously believes that I have misled the Senate, he may censure me. The fact that he has not or does not bother but continues to raise this issue suggests that he either does not have the guts or lacks the courage of his convictions. In these circumstances, I say to Senator Crane: piss or get off the pot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Madam Lash.
—Would you ask that person to withdraw, Mr President? I am serious, Mr President.
—I realise you are serious, Senator Bishop, but I did not hear the interjection.
—I would have thought that, in the context of censuring and Senator Bishop rising, the interjection was appropriate; but I withdraw.
—I take it that that is a simple withdrawal.
—It is a withdrawal.

—Thank you, Mr President. The point of order I was rising on was to ask you to ask the Minister, Senator Cook, not to further mislead the Senate. A close examination of the record will show that he raised the matter in answer to a dorothy dixer. The facts as he put them out have been proven to be untrue, and saying that he intends to put a statement down somehow to distort the facts as they are now on the record is further misleading the Senate. I ask you to direct him not to so do.
—Order! It is a debating point and I cannot ascertain whether it is right.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to recent shipping tragedies and near tragedies on the high seas and ask whether the Minister can provide details to the Senate of the action currently being pursued by Australia at an international level to address the current incidence of ships being lost at sea. Are there grounds for optimism that significant changes in safety procedures may result in fewer risks in the future for seafarers?

—Honourable senators will recall that on previous occasions in the Senate I have expressed my concern about what has become a very serious international problem, with the loss or serious damage to 39 bulk carriers since January last year, six of which were carrying Australian cargoes, along with the loss of the bow of the Kirki off Western Australia. I indicated to the Senate that it was Australia's intention to pursue, in whatever avenues we could, our concern about this at the international fora that are available for this purpose and to attempt, in the first instance by international agreement, to get an extension of the port inspection program that operates in this country. I am pleased to advise the Senate that we have now had the opportunity to do this. Australia, along with a number of other countries that are similarly concerned, has achieved a positive result.

PARA.TAB: The IMO seventeenth regular session of its biennial assembly concluded in London last week. The IMO has a membership of 135 nation states. Its principal safety and pollution prevention conventions apply to about 97 per cent of the world's shipping. The meeting passed a resolution permitting an extension of the current port state control inspection program. This program enables Australia and other signatories to the conventions to conduct inspections of foreign ships visiting their ports. The extension provides a basis for more effective protection of our ports and marine environment by encouraging examination of the ships' crews performance of basic on-board safety related functions.

As I have said to the Senate before, one of the serious problems with foreign shipping in Australia is not only the physical condition of the ships but also the very poor state of training of their crews. This examination would include communication and proficient operation of equipment involved with lifesaving, firefighting and pollution prevention. Deficiencies in these aspects of ship operation have been identified as factors in recent shipping accidents.

In the most recent session of the IMO's maritime safety committee, a working group was established to monitor the extent of compliance of its members with major conventions. This is in the light of clear breaches of these requirements by certain flag states, demonstrated by the results of port state control inspections. Australia, through the Australian Maritime Safety Authority's representations, will be seeking participation in that working group.

The IMO is also reviewing the cause of vessel loss through its specialist subcommittee structure and AMSA will be making an input to this as well. In particular, AMSA will be submitting the findings from its recently commenced pilot study to investigate the way in which existing ship and terminal data on bulk carrier loadings may be used to identify and quantify possible factors in recent ship losses. I would add that these ship losses have occasioned very significant loss of human life.

This study complements research programs also being conducted by international classification societies and other bodies to examine factors possibly relevant in recent vessel losses, including the design of the vessels, ageing, loading and discharge methods, heavy weather and cargo types. Australia supports this activity within the international community to reduce the current alarmingly high loss of life associated with recent ship losses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of claims in the media that, rather than becoming a clever country, Australia is now a stupid society; that while other countries have computers and other technology as their highest growth industries, Australia has real estate? We are in fact selling the farm. In view of this, while the Minister rightly supports fast tracking major projects costing over $100m, which often have only very small employment prospects, he refuses to support a number of smaller projects such as the world patented collapsible container which has the potential to create 2,000 jobs and save up to $100m by reducing empty sea container movements, all for a cost of $25m. Should we not be looking, as the major priority, at employment prospects, rather than export potential?

—That was a very clever question. I am not aware of claims in the media that Australia is a stupid society rather than a clever country. I guess Senator Walters has distilled that from page 2 of the Weekend Australian where there were a number of figures relating to growth areas in the Australian economy during the 1980s. If Senator Walters compares those figures with the figures for the 1970s and the 1960s, she will find there is not much difference between them in terms of growth areas and activity. To be quite frank, I do not know about these collapsible containers that Senator Walters is talking about. I suppose they are a Tasmanian invention, but I do not know.

PARA.TAB: One of the tests of this question is performance growth, particularly in respect of manufactured exports and research and development performance. These are the tests of whether—to use Senator Walters's expression—we are becoming a clever country or whether we are a stupid society.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a share of world trade.

—Yes, I understand that. I now have to deal with Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection. When we are diversifying an economy from one which was 80 per cent dependent on raw materials to one which is significantly less dependent on raw materials as exports, we start from a low base. I think I am not going overboard when I say that the growth in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, has been phenomenal in the last few years. There was a 26 per cent growth in manufactured exports last year, and most of it to the Asia-Pacific region. There was a more significant proportion than ever before of elaborately transformed manufactures.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, there has been a considerable international enhancement of Australia's profile as producers of high quality scientific instruments and high quality software; and good providers of systems integration and a variety of engineering capacities. The reputation of this country has grown significantly. I will certainly follow up this answer by giving Senator Walters figures on the growth in elaborately transformed manufactured exports over the last few years.

The other point that I should make is that there has also been a significant growth in R and D and a significant growth in relationships between R and D institutions and industry, which has been proceeding fairly satisfactorily.

Senator Walters ended her question by asking me whether we should concentrate on employment rather than exports. My answer is that, important as employment is, it is not susceptible to a simple answer. Those companies in Australia which have had fewer reductions in employment have been export companies. Export companies, in times of a recession, have a cushion against a downturn in the domestic market because of their export activities. Exports engender a whole range of indirect employment opportunities, apart from those directly employed in a particular exporting business.
The last part of the question is not as thoughtful as the earlier part and I do not think Senator Walters can differentiate in the way that she sought to do in that part of the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the statement of Mr Grant Latta, the Chief Executive of the Petersville food division, reported in this week's Business Review Weekly. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: Some of the produce Petersville uses should not be bought in Australia. That is certainly the case with tomatoes and asparagus and perhaps corn and potatoes.

Is the Minister aware that imported tomatoes from Italy receive a subsidy of $425 a tonne; imported asparagus receives export enhancement subsidies from the Canadian Government; imported corn receives export enhancement subsidies from the US Government; and imported potatoes receive export enhancement from the EEC? While recognising the right of Petersville to buy its product at the best commercial rate, what is the Government going to do to stop this flood of subsidised produce entering Australia now that Australian processors are refusing to buy Australian products because of the cheap subsidised imports being allowed virtually unrestricted access to Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —If subsidised products are entering the market in Australia to compete with properly produced Australian products there are, if that involves any question of dumping, anti-dumping mechanisms to which I have referred. The Government, in its most recent industry statement, announced that the regulations and procedures to deal with anti-dumping complaints have been modified. That is to facilitate exactly the sort of complaint that is now more frequently being voiced—that the procedures required some refurbishing in order to speed up dealing with genuine anti-dumping complaints. It is not a matter for the Government to initiate those actions; it is for those who believe that dumping is occurring and are offended by it to do so.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the other issues in this question, I am advised that there have been recent price negotiations between potato growers and processors in Western Australia, Tasmania and Victoria, and that the agreed prices for this season are lower than last year but that this is as a result of the prevailing market conditions in Australia. I think the implication of Senator Boswell's question was that prices have changed because of external factors. The advice that I am given is that in the negotiations between growers and processors, prices have changed because of a number of other conditions relative to Australia.

I am also advised that the risk to Australian producers from imports of potatoes from overseas is very low. For example, potato imports accounted for less than one per cent of the total consumption of potatoes produced last year. In the case of corn—another issue which Senator Boswell mentioned in his question—there is a similar situation. With respect to tomatoes, there are imported processed products. This matter is being considered as an anti-dumping case and it will be reported on by 5 December.

I should note that Australia is, on the whole, a net exporter of horticultural products. The Government has always acknowledged the concerns of growers, but the concerns expressed are required to be grounded in facts, and the facts from which concerns are expressed are not always justified.

As Senator Boswell would know because we have often debated this matter here, Australia is on the record as not hiding behind artificial trade barriers and subsidies. That is our position, and it is confirmed by the position we have adopted in the GATT Round in order to try to loosen artificial restrictions on agricultural trade in the world and open up a free trade in agricultural products.

It behoves us to conduct our affairs properly and with principle in order to see that we, as the advocate for freer trade, are not fingered by some of the people we are targeting for applying different conditions to ourselves from the ones we are asking them to apply to themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. The disability reform package which commences today initially contained a requirement for young people in nursing homes to pay a resident contribution which was a percentage of their pension and which would have severely financially disadvantaged them. Can the Minister say what action the Government has taken to protect the interests of these young people?
—Some honourable senators will recall that this matter was raised in Estimates.
—By Senator Walters.

—Yes, I would have to say that Senator Walters was the person who first raised this in Estimates committees. I undertook to follow the matter up with Mr Howe, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, who has primary responsibility for the institutions which are affected. As a result of that consultation, it has been decided that clients of the larger accommodation services who are required to pay a contribution based on a percentage of the pension plus rent assistance should have their contribution calculated as a percentage of the applicable pension plus rent assistance rather than at the full adult rate.

PARA.TAB: The effect of that is to reduce the contributions which would have been payable by young people who are granted this new disability support pension after today. It will ensure that they will have sufficient disposable income to meet their needs. There is obviously a flow-on effect in that some service providers must inevitably suffer a reduction in the amount that they receive. I think the Government has to take some steps to rectify that. So, consistent with the intentions of the disability reform package to protect the interests of both accommodation service providers and clients, those service providers will be reimbursed under the Disability Services Act and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act for any reduction in income they might suffer as a result of the new system, which begins from today.

Under the National Health Act or the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act, a different approach will apply. It will include a change in that legislation scheduled for the autumn session. Residents of services funded under those Acts will continue to pay the full adult contribution. However, they will be reimbursed so their contribution is only a percentage of the 16- to 20-year-old rates. We estimate that all of that should affect only 280 people in a full year. It is not going to affect a great many people, but obviously for those 280 it is a pretty vital decision.

—I do not have any current brief from Mrs Kelly on the national museum. I will have to get one for Senator Reid, and I will endeavour to do that before the end of Question Time.

Is it true that Dr Hall was sacked from his previous position as director of Forensic Science Technology International? Is this the calibre of person the Government is going to appoint to senior positions of major projects such as MFP Adelaide?
—I have no information about Dr Hall. The position to which he may have been appointed must have been in the ken of the South Australian Government. I will find out, if I can.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. He may recall his answer to my question on 14 October in relation to the definition of `effective life' for depreciation purposes. Senator Button stated:

QUESTION.PARA: were to have the industries preferred definition of effective life, it would be highly beneficial for investment, but it would be disastrous for the revenue base of this country.

Can the Minister explain to the Senate what is the point of industry pursuing economic efficiency if the Government is not prepared to provide adequate incentives, such as appropriate depreciation relief?

TALK.START.PARA: —Any taxation regime has to provide a balance between the legitimate concern of government of fostering investment or whatever it may be—
—You are supposed to be examining these things at the moment.

—Just let me answer the question. A taxation regime has to strike a balance between that objective and the objective of keeping the revenue system effective and honest. That balance has to be struck in every circumstance. If Senator Watson is asking me whether I would like an improved depreciation regime for Australian companies so they could turn over equipment much faster and so on, my answer to that question is yes, but it is again a question of striking a balance in the context of the government process overall.

PARA.TAB: What I meant on the last occasion was that there was a view emanating from certain sections of industry in respect of the depreciation regime which would have allowed companies to write off equipment over two years, pass it on to a subsidiary company, which would then write it off again. —On 7 November, Senator Short asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question relating to the processes for setting interest rates, which followed an article in the Australian a few days before. The Treasurer has provided me with an answer which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The process of setting short term interest rates involves the Reserve Bank Board and a process of regular consultation between the Reserve Bank Governor and the Treasurer as well as consultation at the official level. The Secretary of the Treasury is a member of the Reserve Bank Board. Moreover, Section 13 of the Reserve Bank Act requires that the Governor and the Secretary to the Treasury maintain close liaison with each other and keep each other informed of all matters which jointly concern the Bank and the Department of the Treasury.

The Reserve Bank Board did not meet in August. Given the available evidence on the state of the economy, including the June quarter CPI data released on 7 August and the June quarter National Accounts released on 15 August, there were ongoing consultations at the official level and with the Governor prior to the September meeting of the Reserve Bank Board.

In particular, the Treasurer discussed the matter of monetary policy settings with the Governor at around Budget time and it was agreed to review interest rate settings at the scheduled Board meeting in September. The Governor and the Treasurer had subsequent discussions as to the question of the timing and size of any adjustment.
There was nothing improper about the degree or the manner of those consultations. In particular, there was no question of any change of policy without the involvement of the Reserve Bank Board.

The Board subsequently met on 3 September and the Government and the Board agreed on a reduction in short term interest rates. This was reflected in statements released by the Treasurer and the Governor detailing the reasons for the change. The announcement of that decision was made on the morning of 3 September, in order to ensure that the decision was known to financial markets prior to the closure of a $1.5 billion Commonwealth bond tender at 12.30 on that afternoon.

I also bring to the notice of the Senate a question I asked in Question Time. People in some horticultural industries are having a lot of trouble getting casual workers because of a disincentive for them to work when they are in receipt of the training allowance.Let us take the example of seasonal fruit and vegetable pickers. During the harvesting season, growers are desperate for pickers but potential pickers have no incentive to take on work because if they do they can lose the dole.

PARA.TAB: I did not quite get the answer from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) that I wanted. At the moment, casual agricultural workers can earn approximately $360 a week. But there is no incentive for pickers on the training allowance to undertake extra casual work if they receive between $140 and $368 a fortnight. Their optimum level of income is something like $140 a fortnight. At this level they can maximise their income by working the minimum number of hours. This optimum level is achieved by working approximately two days a fortnight. Until agricultural workers receive an income exceeding $368, which occurs after working five days a fortnight, they do not improve their financial position by one cent, despite working an extra three days.

The Government should be looking at setting a two-week pay period over which the training allowance is broken down into 10 working days. Benefit recipients who work over that period would then have deducted from their training allowance a set amount of the total benefit for every full day they work, irrespective of the wages paid. I believe that that would be a help to the industry.

Further on, the report states that the developing challenge by Chile and Argentina to our traditional Asian apple and pear markets is a growing concern. The report says that to retain or regain these markets better shipping arrangements are essential. Obviously, we all know a bit about some of our shipping arrangements and some of the problems on the waterfront.

My next point relates to food safety. Perhaps Senator Crowley might like to add to this, because I know she was on the agricultural and veterinary chemicals inquiry. The Australian Horticultural Corporation played a major role in the establishment in 1990 of a `fresh produce watch', the objective of which is to provide information on chemical residues to the community and to the fresh fruit and vegetable industries.

In Australia we have good respect for our environment from the people who grow fruit and vegetables and all the other horticultural products. If we are to compete against the rest of the world, it is essential that we use the value of being an isolated continent, away from all the contaminants which exist in other parts of the world, so that we can sell our produce. This is the area in which the fresh produce watch will achieve much for our export industries, especially in the horticultural field.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 11 of 1991-92, Efficiency Audit—Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, The Migration Program—Concessional Family and Independent Entrant Migration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This Auditor-General's report entitled The Migration Program—Concessional Family and Independent Entrant Migration is of some significance because it deals with the clear need for improvement in procedures in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs relating to the migration program for concessional family and independent entry migration. The report focuses on two categories of migration: independent entry and concessional family. Together, these account for 49,000 of the 111,000 places in the 1991-92 migration program. Applicants for both programs are selected on the basis of points testing, including skill and employability.

PARA.TAB: One of the key findings of this Auditor-General's report was that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in recent years considerable attention has been paid to the need for Australia to become `the clever country' and policies and programs in several portfolios have taken account of the national requirement for upgrading the skills of Australian workers, investment in new technologies, and encouragement of a range of activities in which the nation could develop a basis for competition with the rest of the world.
The report says further:
This audit dealt with selection of migrants in categories involving the assessment and testing of employability and skill and rating applicants on that basis.
This is the significant conclusion:

In the light of the national interest in `the clever country' it might have been expected that the process would reflect rising standards and a high priority to selecting persons with skills needed in the Australian work force.
Of course, the Auditor-General found something quite to the contrary, and it is this:
Several of the audit's conclusions suggest, however, that other policy priorities have received greater attention.

.In Family migration, the program structure places the skill tested Concessional Family category on a `residual' basis thus according it a lower priority than the Preferential Family category which is not skill tested.
.A higher than estimated number of approvals in the `demand-driven' Preferential Family category leads to reducing numbers selected in the skill tested category.

.Changes in the points test suggest a partial withdrawal from a formerly close nexus between occupational skills, qualifications and experience. It is now less difficult for some applicants to be classified as skilled.

.Comparing the skill tested categories, Concessional Family applicants receive the advantage in the points test of a lower Pass mark than Independent Entry applicants, and may also receive substantial points towards the mark from family connections with a sponsor.
.The test process accords only marginal additional recognition to skills and occupations in short supply in Australia. There are no adjustments to reflect occupations in oversupply.
The report concludes:

These factors influence the process in directions away from the selection of the most skilled applicants, whose employment could make a substantial contribution towards the objective of a better skilled Australian work force.

This is fairly damning criticism of the Department's approach to immigration and, of necessity, the approach of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and the Government. The debate on immigration has heated up in recent times. One would have thought that the Government would be a little more sensitive not only to the economic requirements but also to the general requirements in the area of migration, particularly at a time when the level of immigration is falling substantially. Having increased to something like 140,000 in 1989-90, it is now declining to 111,000 in the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the Auditor-General's comments are particularly serious. Simply on a spot audit basis, the Auditor-General points out not only that more weight appears to be given to non-skill factors but also that some bad decisions appear to have been made. The Auditor-General considers, as a result of the spot audit, that the Department should closely monitor the effect of the change by direct analysis of applicant point scores. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: DILGEA's method of classifying skilled arrivals and evaluating the skill outcome would not disclose the numbers of migrants with the lower levels of experience permitted by the 1990-91 test. The ANAO considers there is scope for adjustment to points test arrangements to provide a higher level of recognition of skills in short supply, and to discourage applications from persons in occupations in which there are no shortages.
As to whether the wrong sorts of people may have been getting in, the Auditor-General states:
. . . the results indicated—
that is, the audit—

that more weight had been given to factors such as an applicant's relationship with a permanent resident than to misconduct, including alleged breaches of the law. Some cases had been approved despite questionable actions by applicants.

This is quite serious stuff. It extends beyond the level of whether it is the right theoretical structure to apply to one's migration program. There are also, obviously, concerns about the actual checking of the people who have come in. In addition, the Auditor-General deals with the general question of quality assurance. The report states:
The ANAO found that some supervisory checking of decision makers took place, and some rejected applications were reviewed through appeal procedures.
The report concludes:
However, the methods observed were inadequate to provide an organised program of quality assurance.

That is, decisions are being made which do not have an organised program of quality assurance. In all, this is a very important document. I commend the Auditor-General for the report. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS)
AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

Mr President, I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and India and Australia and Poland.
The Bill will insert the texts of the agreements into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as schedules to that Act.

The Polish and Indian agreements, which were signed on 7 May 1991 and 25 July 1991 respectively, deal with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and those countries. Details of each agreement were announced and copies made publicly available at time of signature.

Both agreements generally accord with other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years but the agreement with India differs from them in certain respects. Those differences reflect a balancing of Australia's interests with India's position as a major developing country and importer of technology.

A notable feature of the agreement with India in that regard is the royalty provisions, which prescribe different source country tax rate limits for various categories of royalty payments and provide for fees for services to be treated as royalties in specified limited circumstances.

Another feature of the agreement with India is that it provides for "tax sparing" credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by India under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment.

Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives, the agreement calls for a tax credit to be allowed by Australia for the Indian tax forgone. By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian firms and allow them to compete for business in India on favourable terms.

The agreement with India will enter into force when the Australian and Indian Governments have exchanged diplomatic notes advising each other that the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreement the force of law in their respective countries have been completed. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia for those purposes.

Conclusion of the agreement with Poland is indicative of Australia's support for that country's moves towards democratic structures and economic reforms. That agreement will enter into force on the date of exchange of instruments of ratification. This ratification process would also follow the enactment of this Bill.

The Government believes the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and India and Australia and Poland, but it is not possible to predict the eventual effect on the revenue.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the income thresholds below which married couples and sole parents will not be called on to pay any levy.
For 1991-92, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $11,745 will not be required to pay the levy. This threshold is unchanged from the previous year.
Married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $19,674 will not be required to pay the levy for the income year 1991-92.
The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will continue to be increased by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student.
For example, a married couple with three dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $25,974.
The estimated cost of the increased low income threshold is nil in 1991-92 and $10 million in 1992-93.
The change in low income thresholds will not be reflected in provisional tax raised for 1991-92 as the amounts involved would be very small for individual taxpayers.

It is not proposed to amend the tax instalment schedules to take account of the change until 1 July 1992. The number of people from whom the levy is deducted in PAYE instalments and who would be affected by the change would be relatively small.
On the other hand changing the PAYE instalment schedules would involve an administrative cost to the Government and there would also be a substantial administrative cost to the business community.
The Explanatory Memorandum accompanying this Bill contains more detailed explanation of the provisions of this Bill.

MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1991

Australia must have effective immigration controls to ensure that only those persons who are entitled to enter and remain in Australia do so. This Bill contains amendments to the Immigration Act 1958 which will strengthen the effectiveness of Australia's immigration controls. These amendments will place in the Migration Act a power to obtain information to identify and locate illegal entrants and create offences relating to the arrangement and use of contrived marriages or de facto relationships to obtain residence in Australia.
The Bill also includes a power to limit the number of applications which may be considered within a specified class of visa or entry permit.

The Government will not tolerate the continued presence of illegal entrants in Australia. In August 1990, we introduced an enhanced compliance strategy which included measures to reduce the number of people illegally in Australia and to discourage further illegal entrants. These measures were further bolstered by the provision of additional resources in this year's budget. They are producing results. However, additional powers are necessary to detect illegal entrants, including overstayers. The Government must be able to obtain information about their identity and location. The information gathering provisions included in the Bill will authorise the Minister to obtain information, including documents, about the identity or whereabouts of suspected illegal entrants.

However, the Government recognises that a person's privacy should not be intruded upon without clear justification. The provisions of proposed Division 1A allow information or documents to be sought only where the Minister has reason to believe that the person in relation to whom the information is sought is an illegal entrant. Furthermore, the provisions can only be used where the person from whom the information is sought is capable of providing it.

Senators, there are people who will go to extreme lengths to enter or remain in Australia. These lengths include entering into contrived marriages or de facto relationships with Australian citizens or permanent residents. While there are cases where the Australian party willingly lends himself or herself to the contrived relationship, it should also be pointed out that there are cases where the Australian party is misled.

The use of contrived marriages or de facto relationships for obtaining residence in Australia is unacceptable. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations and the Migration Committee of the National Population Council have examined the use of contrived marriages and de facto relationships to gain residence in Australia. The result has been strong recommendations to Government to adopt firm measures to discourage this practice.

The Government will not tolerate the activities of persons conducting business as arrangers of false marriages or de facto relationships for migration purposes. Severe penalties are necessary to punish those involved and to discourage any other persons from considering involvement in this disgraceful business.
The arrangement of a non-genuine marriage or de facto relationship for migration purposes will be punishable by a penalty of 10 years imprisonment or a fine of $100,000 or both.

It is also essential that the Government discourage persons from entering into fraudulent relationships. For this reason a term of 2 years imprisonment may be imposed on the Australian citizen or permanent resident who is convicted of nominating another person as his or her spouse where that person has no intention of living in a genuine and continuing marital or de facto relationship. The person who applies for residence on the basis of the contrived relationship may not only be subject to two years imprisonment upon conviction, but may also be removed from Australia as an illegal entrant.
This complements the Government's earlier introduction of longer qualification periods to demonstrate the genuine and continuing nature of relationships and to discourage fraudulent relationships.

The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has been advised that there are a number of people providing supporting statements which claim that others are in a genuine and continuing relationship when in fact they are not. It is necessary for the law to provide a check to ensure that persons making supporting statements are certain of their facts. Offences have been created for knowingly making a false or misleading statement, or making a false or misleading statement without having made sure that the statement was correct.

These offences will only be operative when the departmental form on which the supporting declaration is made contains a warning of the penalties for making such false or reckless statements. Persons wishing to provide supporting statements will be clearly warned by the notice on the form of the possible consequences if their statement is false or misleading.
When this Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives it made no provision for penalising fraudulent interdependency relationships.

Because the rules which apply to such relationships have only recently been regulated there is no evidence of fraud in this category. However the sentiments expressed by the Opposition on this issue in the House were taken into account and the Government amended the Bill.

This extends the scope of the fraudulent relationships provisions. The offences which relate to non genuine marital and defacto relationships are now mirrored in relation to the interdependency category.

Senators will recall that on 30 April of this year the Minister announced the Government's decision to introduce a `special assistance' category in the 1991-92 migration program. This new category has been established to target people in need who do not meet the refugee and other special humanitarian criteria but who nevertheless are considered by the Government to have special humanitarian claims on Australia. In the past these groups did not qualify under existing program criteria.

The `special assistance' category will be introduced by regulation. As announced in April, decisions will be made each year by the Government on groups which are identified as being eligible and the numbers which can be accommodated. The Government recognises that program capacities will be limited. For this reason the Bill will amend the Act to allow the Minister by gazettal to set a limit on the number of places available.
The changes proposed by clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill mean that once the announced program limit is reached there would be no further consideration of applications.

These application `capping' powers will only apply to those classes where use of the power is specifically permitted under the regulations. The powers are, in effect, an extension of the capping powers already found in sections 28 and 40 of the Act. As I have mentioned, their introduction is principally intended to give effect to the new `special assistance' category. The Government does not rule out the possibility of using the powers in relation to other humanitarian responses which may need to be put in place in the future. We need to have available the legislative tools to respond flexibly to the growing mass movement of peoples throughout the world.
Senators can be assured that this power will not be used in relation to preferential family cases. This would be consistent with the approach already reflected in sections 28 and 40 of the Act.
Any person who lodges a fee with an application which is subject to the capping power will have the fee returned if the application falls outside the capped number.

A further amendment to be made to the Migration Act by this Bill will allow criteria in the regulations to include, by reference, matters published by notice in the gazette from time to time. This will overcome the limitation imposed by section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act requiring these notices to be in existence at the time the regulation is made.

In conclusion, Mr President, these amendments demonstrate the Government's continued vigilance to ensure that the effectiveness of Australia's immigration controls is maintained and, where necessary, enhanced so that only those persons with a right to enter and remain in Australia may do so.
The amending provisions will not impact on the costs of administering the migration program.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
FINANCIAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 will simplify the statutory procedures for approval of new coin issues under the Currency Act 1965 and remove potential ambiguities in the wording of sections 13 and 14 of that Act. The Bill also effects two minor amendments to the Financial Corporations Act 1974, and repeals the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982.

The statutory procedures under the Currency Act 1965 for the approval of new coins, or variations to design or other characteristics of existing denominations, were drawn up at a time when the number of new numismatic or collector coins was very small.

However, in recent years there has been a considerable increase in the number of such coins being issued under the programmes of both the Royal Australian Mint and the Gold Corporation, a statutory authority of the WA Government that produces precious metal coins.
Under the present arrangements, considerable administrative effort is required before the necessary Executive Council approval is obtained for any variation to the currency regulations.
Apart from the drafting and preparation of additional documentation, the procedures can involve time delays, particularly as executive council only meets periodically.
Such delays can create difficulties for the marketing programmes associated with the launch of new collector coins.

The proposed amendments to sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act contained in this Bill are designed primarily to provide the Treasurer with the authority to approve new coins, or determine variations to designs or other characteristics of existing denominations by means of a disallowable instrument, thereby dispensing with the need to refer such matters to the Executive Council.
It is anticipated that this simplified procedure will offer administrative savings.
In all other respects, the effect of the arrangement will be the same as the making of a regulation.
In particular, there will be the same opportunity for parliamentary scrutiny as that which currently exists.

The remaining amendments to sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act are designed to remove possible ambiguities arising from the amendments to the Act made in 1987 to facilitate the production of the same coin denomination in different metallic compositions.

The amendments to the Financial Corporations Act 1974 will permit the Treasurer to delegate to the Governor or Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia the responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions which fall under the Act.
The amendments will also permit the Treasurer to publish the varied list in a manner or form he or she thinks appropriate.
These amendments are intended to simplify administrative processes but do not affect the substance of the Act.

The Special Employment-Related Programs Act 1982 was enacted by the former Fraser Government to appropriate moneys saved under wage pause arrangements for Commonwealth employees up to a total of $300 million for the purposes of employment generating programs. The Act provided that subsidies were not to be payable in respect of employment after 30 June 1984.
By agreement with the States, who administered the program, $200 million was allocated for employment programs and the remaining $100 million was provided for welfare housing.

All activities under the Act are obviously complete and all moneys paid out have been satisfactorily accounted for. As the Act is now spent, the Government is taking the opportunity afforded by the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill to remove it from the statute books.
Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1991

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 provides for initial grants to the States for TAFE for 1992 and for supplementation to 1991 grants to reflect increases in price levels.

The Bill implements the Budget decision to provide for a real increase of 5% in Commonwealth recurrent grants to TAFE. This is in line with the recommendations of the 1990 Deveson Report into training costs. Overall levels of funding for TAFE will be reviewed further in the context of the consideration by State, Federal and Territory Ministers of the findings of the recently released Finn Committee Report.
The effect of the changes is that the Bill provides for $157,385,000 for Recurrent funding and $215,528,000 for Capital funding in 1992 and an additional $1,660,000 for Recurrent funding for 1991.

HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (NO.2) 1991

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, which provides for Commonwealth grants of financial assistance to the States, the Northern Territory and higher education institutions for higher education purposes.

The Bill provides funds for higher education amounting to some $3.6 billion in 1994, i.e. the third year of the new funding triennium, 1992-94. This amount takes into account the Government's decisions to provide, in 1994, some $44 million for 2845 additional student intakes, some $277 million for capital works and additional funds amounting to just under $75 million for a new funding program to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education. These decisions were announced subsequent to those on higher education which formed part of the Government's 1991-92 Budget.

The Government's new funding program to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education is one of a number of initiatives to promote quality and diversity in the development of higher education through the 1990s. The focus of the Government's new policies is a comprehensive set of measures to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision. The extra funds will be used to reward institutions for making the best use of all their available resources. The Higher Education Council has been asked to explore the characteristics of quality in higher education. After the Council reports on this reference, and following wider consultation with the higher education sector, a national structure, independent of government, will be established to report on the application and effectiveness of quality enhancement measures developed by institutions. A National Centre for Teaching Excellence in higher education is to be set up next year to examine and disseminate information about good teaching practices. Funding will also be made available for a pilot credit transfer project, under the aegis of the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, which the Government hopes will lead to the establishment of a national credit transfer agency. In addition, a comprehensive review of modes of delivery in higher education will be conducted to look at how technology can best be harnessed to improve access to, and the quality and efficiency of, higher education.

With these measures, the Government is taking the lead internationally in providing a funding incentive to institutions, over and above funding for student load, to promote the highest possible level of quality in higher education.

It needs to be stressed that institutional participation in the new quality assurance arrangements will be voluntary and the allocation of normal operating grants will be unaffected. It is certainly not the Government's intention to use the new arrangements to redistribute operating grants to institutions on the basis of comparative quantitative performance indicators. These quality assurance initiatives will be developed hand in hand with all of the main interest groups within the higher education system.

It is worth emphasising also that the Government's approach to quality assurance balances institutional autonomy with public accountability. It is based primarily on self assessment by institutions rather than relying on external assessments of quality. It relates the monitoring of quality to the goals of individual institutions. It involves assessments which include both qualitative and quantitative indicators. It allows for comparisons to be made against the different circumstances of institutions, including the composition of their student population, and their performance over time. It should thereby encourage diversity and innovation while confirming public confidence in the higher education system and reinforcing its international reputation.

The Bill also provides for a number of decisions on higher education announced in the Budget. It includes provisions to widen the definition of higher education capital projects to encompass other than simply building projects. This will enable the Government to support major investments in course material and equipment which are genuine capital substitutes. The wider definition recognises the potential for new technologies and alternative delivery modes to improve delivery of, and access to, higher education.

The Bill provides for the Government's decisions aimed at addressing enrolment and overcrowding pressures being felt in higher education institutions. To this end, just under $10 million has been allocated for additional student intakes next year with additional funds to take account of the pipeline effect of these intakes. As well, an additional $54 million is being provided for capital projects next year to alleviate pressures of overcrowding, of which some $24 million is funding originally earmarked for 1994. About half of these funds will be used to assist institutions to refurbish and renovate existing space. These funds will be provided on a matching basis with institutions.

A pilot scheme will begin next year which will see the Government and employers sharing the costs of providing a number of additional student intakes, with the Commonwealth's share at 60 percent. The Government has allocated just under $3.5 million for up to 600 new student intakes in 1992 and some $4 million for 700 intakes in both 1993 and 1994 with additional funds for the pipeline effects of these intakes.

The Bill provides funds for a Commonwealth program to establish three advanced engineering centres in partnership with host institutions and industry. The focus of the centres will be on advanced undergraduate and postgraduate education and training. However, the centres will also provide courses for industry and Technical and Further Education teachers. They will also provide professional retraining for experienced engineers and applied research and design services for industry. The Commonwealth is providing just under $10 million over the triennium for establishment and ongoing costs associated with this initiative.

The Bill provides extra financial assistance amounting to some $31 million over the triennium for additional Australian Research Council grants and provides over $10 million in additional funds for support programs for Aboriginal students. Increased funding amounting to some $350 million over the period 1991-93 is also provided in accordance with the Government's arrangements for cost supplementation of institutions' operating grants. A major component of this is funding to fully supplement pay rises awarded to academics by the Industrial Relations Commission in its decision of 23 July 1991.

To enable Victoria's share of the responsibility for funding the higher education program at the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture to be transferred to the Commonwealth, the Bill includes a financial adjustment to the maximum grants for higher education institutions. This will mean that the College's program is funded fully through the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 as from 1 January of next year. A complementary amendment to the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991 will have the effect of reducing the financial assistance grants in the case of the State of Victoria. Taken together, these amendments will have no net effect on total Commonwealth outlays and are being introduced at the request of the Victorian State Government.

As announced in the Budget, the Bill also provides for an increase in the annual course contribution under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. From next year, the annual course contribution for a full-time student undertaking a standard program of study will increase to $2250—an increase of $144 above the normal indexation increase—to help fund further expansion of the higher education system.

The Government has committed itself to spending some $12.9 billion on higher education over the 1992-94 triennium. Continued growth in the system will provide expanding opportunities for Australians to participate in higher education, and with the Government's new measures to further enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision, Australian students can expect to receive a higher education the standard of which continues to be the equal of any in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to give effect to decisions on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1992 announced in the March 12 Industry Statement and in the 1991-92 Budget. It will also provide for supplementation of grants appropriated for schools programs for 1991 and for initial appropriations for schools programs for 1992.
The proposed new National Element of the Country Areas Program will provide funds for national projects to increase the number of students in country areas completing 12 years of schooling.
The proposed new School Language and Literacy Program, announced in the context of the White Paper on the Australian Language and Literacy Policy, will have four elements:

Under the Priority Languages Incentive Element schools will be eligible for $300 for each Year 12 student completing a course in a priority language, up to a maximum of 25 per cent of all Year 12 students;
Under the Community Languages Element funds will be provided to support the study of community languages at school level;
$1.024 million will be available under the Literacy and Learning National Element in 1992 to support national projects aimed at enhancing language, literacy and learning; and
Professional development programs related to enhancing literacy and learning at secondary level will be supported under the Literacy and Learning General Element.
The existing Ethnic Schools and Literacy and Learning Programs will be subsumed under this new program from 1992.

The Bill also provides additional funds under the Award Restructuring Assistance Program to meet the Commonwealth's share of the cost of the introduction of Advanced Skills Teacher positions, and of the increase in the salary benchmark for 4 year trained teachers to $38,000 per year.

As announced in the 1991-92 Budget, this Bill also proposes to defer part of total expenditure on government schools under the Senior Secondary Support Element of the Capital Grants Program until the 1993 program year. It also provides for stage one in the implementation of the phasing out of prospective cost supplementation arrangements for non-government schools. By 1995, non-government schools will be supplemented retrospectively, in December of each year, as is currently the case for government schools.

Recent amendments of the Migration Act 1958 necessitate consequential amendments to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to ensure that refugees remain eligible for the relevant schools programs.

The Bill provides for additional funds for 1991 programs in line with cost supplementation arrangements to bring total funding for 1991 programs to an estimated $2,503 million. It appropriates an estimated $2,592 million for schools programs for 1992.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
