TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on this Bill was adjourned last evening I was describing the purpose of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991, which is a traditional machinery Bill which implements the decisions agreed at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council on 31 May this year. The Bill provides for general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1991-92 for an amount totalling $13.7 billion. That is approximately half the total Commonwealth payments to the States this financial year, the other half being paid in the form of special purpose grants basically under section 96 of the Constitution, which special purpose grants, of course, have particular terms, conditions and strings attaching to them in terms of their usage. The Bill implements the decision to pay to the States the $13.7 billion in general purpose payments, without any strings attached, for use by the States in whatever way they wish to use those funds.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition, of course, does not oppose this Bill. It is a traditional machinery Bill and we will be supporting it, although I will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion.

I also said last night before the debate was adjourned that the fact that yesterday the Premiers very understandably decided to abandon their participation in the Special Premiers Conference which was scheduled for Perth on 21 and 22 November—that is, next week—is a very sad decision indeed. It was a very understandable decision on the part of the States, given the conditions that the Commonwealth was imposing on that conference.

Honourable senators will recall that conference was to be the third Special Premiers Conference which followed the initiative by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in July of 1990 to establish a series of Special Premiers Conferences to examine fundamental reform of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States in various ways: firstly, to delineate better and more clearly than exists now the responsibilities and the functions as between the Commonwealth and the States. We have seen over many decades an increasingly centralist trend in government in Australia, whereby the Federal Government—the Commonwealth Government, the central government of the day—has taken unto itself an increasing number of powers and functions that are traditionally and constitutionally the preserve of the States. One thinks particularly of the areas of education and health and, in the broad sense of the term, many areas of social welfare.

There has been an encroachment by the Federal Government over the State governments for many decades now, and one of the important things that have to be done in this nation of ours, as we move towards the twenty-first century and want to have a more efficient and more competitive federal system, is to have a clearer separation of the functions and a clearer understanding and agreement between the Commonwealth and the States of who is to do what, which are the functions that should be done by the Commonwealth Government and which are the functions that should be done by State and, of course, local governments.

That was an essential part of the process that was envisaged in the Special Premiers Conference machinery. But the other part, and the part without which none of the rest can follow in any lasting and meaningful term, was to have a fundamental review of the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the States, to look at and to do something about the very dramatic imbalance that now exists between the Commonwealth, on the one hand, and the States, on the other, in terms of their relative responsibilities for spending from the public purse and putting money into the public purse.

At the moment, 50 per cent or thereabouts of every dollar of taxpayers' money in this nation that is spent is spent by State governments. But State governments raise only about 20 per cent of the total public sector revenue that is raised. They therefore have a very dramatic, very sharp, imbalance between what they spend, on the one hand, and what they raise, on the other.

In contrast, the Commonwealth Government also spends about 50 per cent of each taxpayer's dollar. But it raises close to 80 per cent of all the revenue raised by governments in Australia. That relative imbalance between the Commonwealth and the States in terms of their revenue raising and spending responsibilities is known in this terrible jargon as vertical fiscal imbalance. It is the mismatching between the revenue raising responsibilities, on the one hand, and the spending responsibilities, on the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't we just say that?

—Why do we not just say that? Senator Kernot is quite right. If we can think of a simpler and less arcane term than `vertical fiscal imbalance' then the debate on this very important subject might be better understood than it is. Indeed, it might be better understood how important the whole debate is.

PARA.TAB: The point to be made is this: unless we do something to correct that imbalance in the financial area between the Commonwealth and the States then we are never going to get a proper functioning of the federal system in the way in which it has always been envisaged to function. The reform of Federal-State relations and in particular Federal-State financial relations—because, as I said, that is what sets the pattern for everything else that happens—was to be a fundamental part of the Special Premiers Conference process. It was the whole reason for establishing the Special Premiers Conferences. It is arguably the most important micro-economic reform that could be undertaken in this Federation of ours over the next 10 years as we move into the twenty-first century.

It is regrettable that the Commonwealth and in particular the Prime Minister, having given the States and the Territories every expectation that the Commonwealth was prepared to look at this subject, have in recent days—and it has culminated in the last 24 hours—completely stepped aside from any prospect now of achieving those worthwhile reforms. Because the Commonwealth Government has said that it is no longer prepared to consider this as an option for debate—it will not allow it to be on the agenda of the conference that had been planned for next week—there is no chance of solving this financial mismatch between the Commonwealth and the States through any hand back to the States of income taxing powers or any arrangement to have an income tax sharing arrangement with the States.

They have done so—and the Prime Minister has announced this—on the flimsiest of explanations and indeed on explanations which are absolutely contrary to what he put to, and agreed with, the Premiers at the first Special Premiers Conference in Brisbane last year and again at the second Special Premiers Conference in Sydney just three or four months ago. Indeed, let me quote one small part of the communique of the first Special Premiers Conference in Brisbane in October 1990, just over a year ago. It said, inter alia:

After the conference, after that communique had been issued, Treasurer Kerin went so far as to say:

Conference, particularly. . . vertical fiscal imbalance. . . Then at an Australian Labor Party business breakfast in Brisbane just a few weeks later, on 27 August, Mr Kerin said that the Federal Government was fully committed to handing substantial taxing powers back to the States as agreed at last month's, that is the July, Special Premiers Conference. This involves removing some of the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance which Mr Kerin described as meaning `he who taxes should be the one who spends it'. He went on to say:
The Commonwealth is really prepared to go as far as we can in that area. We believe it will not impede our ability to manage the economy.

What has happened since those heady days of just a few weeks ago? The thing that has happened is what has been happening to this country for months now, which has produced a policy paralysis in this country; a situation which is adding to the economic misery day by day of hundreds of thousands, indeed millions, of Australians—a policy paralysis which now sees almost one million people in this nation unemployed. If one looks at those that are underemployed the figure is closer to 1 1/2 million people, and that is a conservative estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991 proposes to calculate and appropriate the general purpose grants which are to be paid to the States and to the Northern Territory during the 1991-92 financial year. The Commonwealth has been giving financial assistance to the States since Federation, although the calculation of and rationale for the various grants have varied considerably over time and are now so complex that the question of Federal-State financial relations has become a specific financial discipline.

PARA.TAB: This Bill implements the principal decisions of the May 1991 Premiers Conference, namely, that the level of general revenue grants to the States would be maintained in 1991-92 at the same real level as was provided in 1990-91. This maintenance of the real value of general assistance grants was originally agreed at the June 1990 Premiers Conference and has been honoured by this Government. Secondly, it was decided that the Northern Territory would receive an additional specific assistance grant of $40m in 1991-92, which is less than the $50m provided in the previous year. Thirdly, the level of general purpose capital grants is to be maintained in nominal terms at the 1990-91 level. Lastly, the global borrowing limits for the six States for 1991-92 would total $3,750m.

In addition, the Bill also implements a decision of the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference concerning the land transport package that was negotiated. It was agreed that the funding provided by the Commonwealth to both State and local government in respect of local roads will be untied by being included in the general revenue grants made to State and local government sectors.

Financial grants are based on a per capita relativity which is then multiplied by the actual population of a State or Territory. Thus, the per capita relativities are the key determinant of a State's entitlement. Not surprisingly, the more populous States dispute some of the methodology used in calculating relativities, but the merits of fiscal equalisation—another one of those phrases—have been apparent for decades and are supported by the Australian Democrats.

The current estimate of the funding which will be provided is $13.7 billion. This is an estimate contingent upon the actual movement in the consumer price index being the same as the forecast which was accepted at the Premiers Conference. Where there is some disparity an adjustment will be made.

The Australian Democrats do not oppose this legislation, although I take this opportunity to express our opposition to the policy line which the Government has been pursuing for years with respect to cutting the funds available to the States. We believe that this has meant the deferral or abandonment of many public works projects which should have been undertaken. Child care facilities and the disgraceful neglect shown by the Commonwealth in the area of mainline railways are two examples that come to mind.

The question of grants to the States inevitably leads, and has led in this debate, to the broader question of Commonwealth-State financial relations. This has again become an issue in Australian politics. I say `again' because ever since the Second World War when the Commonwealth became the only Government to levy income tax, there has been a series of calls by the States for more access to growing tax bases. All these calls by the States have despaired that the Commonwealth has retained the goldmine of income tax receipts, yet when pressed—or indeed when they were offered the chance by Prime Minister Fraser—to actually levy a State income tax they have always declined. The events of last week have shown that this is still the position. Their collective position seems to be `Give us more money, yet don't give us any of the political odium which naturally arises when governments tax their constituents'.

It has been interesting to note the way in which the Labor Premier of Queensland readily adopted the catchcry of former National Party Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, of `No new taxes' when he came to power. It seems that few Australians want new taxes, but many want increased services. That leads to an almost insoluble political dilemma and one which is very relevant to the current introduction of the GST debate.

I have some serious reservations about the new federalism agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Australian Democrats believe that a system of strong regional governments is infinitely superior to the current system of State governments, but we recognise that although there is a growing body of public opinion in favour of the abolition of States, this is not realistically achievable in the immediate future. Accordingly, as a matter of urgency and within the significant constraints imposed by the Australian Constitution, we must seek to eliminate the ridiculous inefficiencies which accrue to this country when States pursue competing and uncoordinated strategies and policies on matters of national importance.

The classic example in this regard is the environment. It would lead us to ask how anyone could support a State based system of protecting endangered species of fauna and flora. This means that where an ecosystem straddles a State border the animals will be afforded differing levels of protection depending upon which tree they happen to nest in or which side of the river they happen to dig their burrow.

We believe that the Commonwealth should be given more power in this area and in others of national import. I acknowledge that for the first time a genuine effort is being made to get some consistency into the laws which are administered at the State level. For example, the Queensland Attorney-General, Mr Dean Wells, is leading the charge to establish a uniform crimes Act in this country. It is a massive task, but it is under way. Similarly, there are attempts to unify the various State credit Acts and the eastern States have agreed to a uniform system of defamation law.

The Special Premiers Conference process has produced some incredible results if measured simply in terms of the communiques issued at the end of each well publicised gathering. There is to be a national rail corporation, at this stage only concentrating on interstate freight but with the possibility of passenger services as well. We have also seen a rational approach to pricing road transport for heavy vehicles, the establishment of a properly interconnecting electricity grid in south-eastern Australia, and the mutual recognition of occupational qualifications and goods and services between the States.

In addition, the States are all committed to introducing their financial statements in a comparable manner and to progressively adopting the superior methodology of the Commonwealth and the Australian Bureau of Statistics in regard to budgetary functional classifications. However, apart from the National Rail Corporation, we still simply have the stated intention of the Premiers to deliver these important reforms. It must be remembered that, apart from Queensland, no State Premier controls both houses of parliament. Therefore, there can be no guarantees concerning the passage of the necessary legislation through all State parliaments. Indeed, the sensational announcement last night that the Premiers were pulling out of the scheduled Special Conference in Perth has put a cloud over the complete process—at least in the near future.

The Australian Democrats believe that it is unfortunate that the issue of vertical fiscal imbalance has been addressed in such a narrow manner. If it is conceded that there needs to be a lessening of the degree of imbalance between the revenue resources and the functional responsibilities—and I admit that there is an argument to lessen the imbalance—then why are, or should I say why were, the politicians and the bureaucrats only examining the various options of redistributing the excess revenue of the Commonwealth, instead of also examining the far more promising options of redistributing the excess functions of the State governments and the role of local governments within that?

A former Labor State Premier of New South Wales and a former Governor-General have recently added their voices to those calling for the abolition of the State level of government. The shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Howard, has recently stated his preference for a more rational system of government, which he identified as one of regional representation. I know that that view is certainly in the minority within the Opposition. But it seems ironic to me that the economic rationalists who have dominated the agenda in this country in recent times have not been more consistently vocal about the structural inefficiency of our current federal model, as they would see it. It is the coalition which constantly carps about efficiency in government and which constantly advocates cutting public expenditure. But at the same time the coalition staunchly defends and advocates the existence of State governments.

Even if we were to ignore the evidence of almost endemic corruption at the State level, even if we were to ignore the absurdity of already cash strapped States falling over backwards to offer concessions to attract investments to them in a most parochial way instead of maximising the benefit to Australia of a particular project, even if we were to ignore the absurdity of differing laws applying in Coolangatta from those applying across the street in Tweed Heads or between Canberra and Queanbeyan, I would still submit that we cannot ignore the almost criminal waste of resources which creating multiple competing bureaucracies in almost every function of government must occasion.

The Opposition's second reading amendment is in three parts. The first part is a motherhood statement which, I believe, we can interpret as we wish. To me, the second part—`the refusal by the Commonwealth to contemplate meaningful reform of financial arrangements'—begs the question: what does `meaningful reform' mean? Does it mean giving the States more money with which to run their schools and hospitals or does it imply a narrow definition of vertical fiscal imbalance, which means hiving off many important functions to the States? As I have mentioned, the control of the environment would be of particular concern to us in that debate.

I was asked whether the Australian Democrats were happy little centralists. I think it would be more appropriate to describe us as happy little supporters of strong regional government within a federal system. Within such a structure, where the regional governments are of a size to remain meaningful to the citizens who elect them, one is much more likely to find an interested and participating electorate, and this in turn has the effect of producing a more dynamic and responsive government. The Brisbane City Council is a good example of where the citizenry recently—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to wipe out the States?

—Yes, we do. In the longer term I believe that there is a case for abolishing the States in favour of strong regional governments. That has always been Democrats policy. I am not relating anything new to honourable senators. But I must stress that we have to take a longer term view. In the meantime, we have States and we must look at how the States cooperate within a federal system.

Inevitably, that will lead to delinquency in terms of accountability and responsibility.

Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) understands that. Maybe it was for partisan political reasons, or maybe it was his great leap forward in an effort to distance himself from the former Treasurer and be seen as actually being able to initiate something, that led him to announce that we would have Premiers conferences to set down guidelines for where responsibilities ought to exist. The great tragedy of the imbroglio, the internecine conflict which is going on between the Prime Minister and Mr Keating, is that it has destroyed, for the life of this Government, any prospect of rational debate and any chance of rationalising responsibilities, duties and financial collections and disbursements. To me, that is the horror of recent events. No longer is the Prime Minister able to make altruistic decisions and determinations in the best interests of all Australians; he is now driven by the ambition to retain his own position.

I think it is fair to say that not in recent history have we seen the consensus between the various Premiers that we are seeing now. I suggest that nobody would argue the proposition that the Premiers Conference has been cancelled as part of the staging of some political stunt. It has been cancelled because the Premiers were led to believe—they were a little slower than Paul Keating—that they would be meeting to confirm arrangements which would allow them a share of income tax; nothing new or different, but a share of current income tax. That would have given them certainty, security and, certainly, responsibility. Following that, we would have seen the rearranging of their duties and responsibilities.

One of the great sins in Australia—and I say this as a federalist—is that we have never seen proper demarcation of responsibilities between local, State and Federal governments. The State governments—whether they be Liberal or Labor—want all the rights and none of the responsibilities. I had to say to an ex-State Liberal Minister for education, when he was berating me for my attitude on something, that it is difficult to persuade Australia that the federal system works when, after 90 years, we cannot get six State Ministers for education to agree to children starting school on the same day and in the same year. With the mobile population we have at present, it is absurd that children, when they are transferred with their parents from one State to another, find themselves either a year ahead or a year behind their classmates. If the States cannot get that much right, one wonders whether they are serious about other matters.

Having said that, I think there has been a new understanding on the part of the States that we can no longer play these political games. Meaningful reforms have to take place. I do not think anybody would argue that the present system is working. Nobody would argue that the present system of tied grants is accompanied by proper responsibilities on the part of the States. Nobody would argue that the vertical fiscal imbalance is in any way guaranteed to ensure a fair distribution of accountability and responsibility. Tied grants cause a lack of accountability. They deny local circumstances, and this is why I have always been opposed to the dead hand of centralism. They deny the opportunity for vibrant local decision-making and, inevitably, they load up the cost of monitoring administration and add to the costs of compliance. They create duplication and they guarantee economic inefficiency and a waste of resources.

I am always fascinated to see the Federal Department of Transport and Communications with its responsibility for roads, the State departments with their Ministers for roads and heads of main roads departments, and the shire councils with their preoccupation with roads and footpaths. They all want their share, their responsibility. So we have this enormous triplication. In more recent times, this has become trendy. We have seen the same thing applying in the delivery of health-care and child welfare and child minding centres. This is all the result of a lack of accountability by the various tiers of government for the funds they spend.

I conclude by saying, as I have from the outset, that it is a pity we see this legislation in this form, with a guarantee that it will be in this form in the future. Premier Carmen Lawrence from Western Australia was quite right when she talked about the pilgrimage of the mendicants coming to Canberra—not to be active and meaningful participants in a Premiers conference and not to contribute to the decision-making, but simply to be told what their share will be. I am sure we had all hoped—as Senator Short said, the Liberal Party had given its imprimatur and its support to reforms—that we would see a new form of Premiers conference where everyone would meet for the purpose of a meaningful outcome which, in my view, would have set in place the reformation of responsibilities in this country.

One of the greatest cost burdens that taxpayers bear is that associated with the duplication and triplication of services and the inherent inefficiency that goes with this. Because of the internecine conflict and the power struggle between the former Treasurer and the Prime Minister over one job, that prospect has been scuttled for the life of this Parliament. It shall not be resurrected until there is a new parliament and a new government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an excellent speech by my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne, and I hope the Australian Democrats took notice of it. It is no good railing about an imperfect world; we happen to live in a country which is a federation. The intellectual problems of a federation are quite beyond the Australian Democrats to understand as legislators.

PARA.TAB: I make the point that the federal system of government is simply the hardest system of government to operate. It is the most relevant system of government for a very large country such as Australia. Australia is a huge continent and people live over 3,000 miles apart from one coast to another. The issues that concern them have to be dealt with by people on the spot. The federal system is perfectly proper and the most correct form of government, which ensures a distribution of power close to the points of its application.

The point I would like to make in relation to a federation is the point that has totally escaped the Democrats: it is a difficult system. It is simply the most difficult form of government one can have. I can understand that, with their legislative shortcomings, the Democrats find it attractive—as the Labor Party does—to have a central form of government, where everything is in one spot; if they had a unicameral legislature, the whole thing could be run by a caucus or some other committee and they would not have to listen to anyone or listen to any conflicting advice. But that is a diversion for the moment.

I rose this afternoon to speak to the third part of this excellent amendment that has been moved by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition. I am moved to do that by the incoherence of the Government's response to the problem of a third runway for Sydney. Not only is it an incoherent response, but the Government is also moving at a glacial non-responsive speed in relation to that third runway.

Sydney is the international gateway to Australia. It is the first impression people get when they come to this country. What do they get? They get muddles and delays and incompetence in the air and on the ground with the congestion in the terminals. The second point about Sydney is that it is the focal point for nearly all of Australia's long-haul internal traffic. All the long-haul internal traffic within the country goes through Sydney.

The delays we have suffered in Sydney are now very long standing. They do not go back a few months or a year or two; they go back over a decade. Those delays affect all the air traffic through the country, financially as well as in a large variety of other ways. If there is a half-hour delay in the morning, a ripple effect runs through all the airline schedules for the whole day. People in Perth, Adelaide and Cairns might be half an hour or an hour late in their travels as a consequence of not having enough runway capacity at Sydney.

Of course, the economic penalty is enormous. It has cost the country many hundreds of millions of dollars in fuel burn, crew time, airframe and engine time, plus the penalties business suffers by being held up. It also affects our reputation as a venue for overseas travellers. We are trying hard to make a name for ourselves as a holiday destination for overseas visitors. They have to have an efficient response when they get to Australia. They are not at all amused to be held up in the air for half an hour or delayed by curfew requirements when they want to come into the main point of entry.

I was rather staggered to read recently an article by an economics writer in one of the major dailies claiming that the one thing tourists did have was time, that there were no time pressures on them. I take the contrary view; tourists coming in from our two principal source countries—the United States and Japan—are very short on time. When I was living in the United States I found that people had to work in industry for about two years before they were entitled to any holidays, after which time they got seven or 10 days. At most they got about 14 days if they were working for the average company. When people are coming in with those tight vacation requirements, they have to be able to plan their travel expeditiously. They certainly cannot do that if they are held up getting into and out of Sydney.

My concern about what is happening in Sydney is the delay and prevarication by all the anti groups that are growing because the Government is not getting on with the job. Even today we have been circularised with a notice by some group running a protest meeting in this building about the need to go to Badgerys Creek and turn Sydney Airport into a farm or a residential area. We have the Greens, the environmentalists, the Australian Democrats; we have all those people who bought land near the airport that was cheap because of the disability of having an airport near them and are now pretending to be surprised that the airport should go about its daily business of earning a living by being an airport and having aircraft flying into it.

A whole bunch of strange economics writers are saying that somehow or another it is more efficient to go to Badgerys Creek than to develop Sydney to its maximum potential. I do not know why they do not go to Alice Springs; they would not have any weather problems and a nice new terminal is being developed there. Badgerys Creek is not a substitute for the principal airport of Sydney. Those economics writers who try to prove that Sydney Airport as it stands is not essential fail to understand the importance of an entry point to the country and the place of airports in modern commerce. They are rather like the seaports of old.

The cause of all this debate and the thing that leads to this great cognitive dissonance in the Government is the way the Ministry cannot accept a collective decision and support it. Minister Collins, the Minister primarily responsible for the legislation, will remember the report entitled The Adequacy of International Terminal and Aircraft Handling Facilities at Sydney Airport. A very strongly dissenting report calling for the third runway to be built straight away was put down. Senator Collins opposed that recommendation. Having publicly opposed the third runway, he is now in a position of trying to implement government policy and defend that argument.

I do not know why Minister Baldwin is not required by his colleagues to resign from the Ministry. He is publicly campaigning against the Cabinet decision that there be a third runway. There are also problems in this chamber. Poor old Senator Faulkner cannot even talk to Minister Collins in the corridors. He has to get up and try to skewer him at Question Time with embarrassing questions to find out the state of the game. He is quite clearly totally opposed to the runway, as are Minister Baldwin, Mr Punch and all those righties from the New South Wales camps.

Senator Loosley has given up the Right on this issue. He tries to starch up Senator Collins from time to time to get the runway built. Somewhere in the middle we have Senator West, who really does not know where she is going. She is oscillating like a pendulum between them. Dear old Richo, who is trying to defend his right wing colleagues, really does not know what is happening. In the face of that, the New South Wales Government is saying `Let us build a runway', and nearly all the people of Australia are saying, `Let us put the national interest first and get the runway built'.

Despite all this, we have a lack of purpose, a lack of direction and a lack of consistency from the Government. The consequences of all this are that the economic standards of the country are dragged down by one of the fundamental tools of a modern society not being provided. On those grounds, I support the amendment moved by Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of points need addressing. Senator Kernot in her remarks asked for clarification of what the Opposition means by the words `meaningful reform' in part (b) of the amendment moved by Senator Short. What we mean is no more than some very simple facts.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the existing financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States are patently unsatisfactory. Secondly, it is therefore universally agreed that reform is urgently required. Thirdly, any reform must be meaningful in the sense that it must lead to change and improved arrangements. Just what the change would be is a matter on which we may well disagree, particularly between the Democrats and ourselves, but that is not specifically addressed in the amendment.

The purpose of the amendment is simple: it is to point out the need for meaningful reform. Of course, there are many ways in which that debating process can proceed, should proceed and, in effect, would have been addressed next week by the Premiers Conference if we did not have this political approach to that sort of a problem by such an impotent Prime Minister.Without meaningful reform, the aspirations of the Opposition or the Australian Democrats or, for that matter, the Government will never be capable of being met.

Therefore, I commend to the Australian Democrats the amendment moved by Senator Short and seek their endorsement of it, particularly for clauses (a) and (b). They have certainly made their point clear with regard to the third runway. We would be seeking to word the amendment in such a way as to enable the different expressions to come out. I trust that Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats will be able to join us with regard to clauses (a) and (b) of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I come to talk about the amendment, I want to say a couple of things about the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991 because it seems to have slipped out of the debate a little. For the record, the Bill reflects the decisions taken at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting on 31 May 1991 putting arrangements in place for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1991-92.

PARA.TAB: This is a significant Bill in terms of the amount of money which is being disbursed. It represents about 13 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1991-92—about $13 billion-plus. It reflects one of the significant changes which has recently taken place in Commonwealth-State relations. It is not a change of the fundamental order of magnitude that some were seeking, but it reflects an agreement by the Commonwealth at the 1990 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting to maintain the level of general revenue assistance in real terms for the three years 1991-92 to 1993-94.

There was at that stage a commitment that, should Australia suffer a major deterioration in its economic circumstances, that agreement would be reviewed.Nonetheless, at the 1991 conference the Commonwealth agreed to honour that undertaking and, in return, the States undertook to focus their adjustment efforts on restraint in outlays, and to use increases in taxes and charges only as a last resort. The balancing item for the Commonwealth's agreement to honour its undertaking has been an honouring by the States in their 1991-92 Budgets of their undertaking—not that there have been no tax increases, but substantially they have not used that as their first mechanism. That is important and it is a sign of a healthy relationship and the healthy discussions which took place at that Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting which led to these Bills. That is essentially the background to this legislation. The rest is incorporated in the second reading speech.

I now wish to talk about the amendment. Essentially, it falls into two parts: that which relates to the financial arrangements between the States; and, dragged in from the back streets—not exactly relating to this Bill, but nevertheless dragged in—the question of the third runway, which I will come to in a moment. First of all, I will talk about calling off the Special Premiers Conference.

I make it absolutely clear that the Commonwealth has not in any way called off or sought to have adjourned, deferred or called off the Special Premiers Conference. We want it to continue because there are important reforms that can be discussed and should be discussed, but we are not prepared to do so at the price of the introduction of a State income tax. There is an important reform process under way which we believe should be continued. There have been a very proud number of steps forward in Commonwealth-State relations as a result of the Special Premiers Conference process, and I think it is important that it should continue. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made it clear that it is his view that the Perth conference should proceed as planned.

Australia has already gained a lot from the Special Premiers Conference process. We have the National Rail Corporation, which Senator Kernot correctly referred to, which in my view is the most substantial of the changes. That is a very subjective view and people may have other views, but of itself it is certainly important, and it has the potential to become even more important. There are the road transport reforms and the electricity grid reforms on the east coast which, perhaps, others would consider to be more important than the first two. But the ranking is not relevant; those are three important changes. The mutual recognition of standards is long overdue and means at least that some of those arrangements which the sovereign countries of the European Community have reached amongst themselves are starting to be applied to the States within our federation.

There has been significant progress in reviewing functional areas of government activity and there are important processes still to be undertaken. There are other important matters on the agenda for this conference, to which I wish to refer in a moment, which should have been considered. If the States were discharging their responsibilities to their constituents—to their voters, to their citizens—they would be meeting properly to consider these matters instead of doing a bit of grandstanding, trying to get their hands on the money. I will come back to those matters because I think they are important in the consideration of whether one should support this amendment.

It is obvious that the States would want the proposal that they have put forward because it means more revenue and no increased responsibility for the States. It is hardly surprising that they would want it. It is somewhat more surprising that the Opposition seems to be supporting it. I would have thought that anybody seriously trying to address the national economic interest could not propose the opportunity for the States to have that share of income tax and the capacity to influence the level at which income tax is levied. To restrict the capacity of the Commonwealth effectively to manage the economy would not be supporting the proposal. Perhaps Opposition members have not read it or perhaps they do not understand it. I am very surprised and very interested that they should be proposing this idea that the States should also be able to levy an income tax but not have to have the sordid responsibility of passing the laws to do so—of pursuing the debtors. All the odium falls on the Commonwealth. Every time people fail to pay, the Commonwealth has to pursue them, but the money goes to the States.

If I were a State Premier I might think, `Maybe the Commonwealth is looking away. It might not see the national interest impact of these proposals. We might slip it past them', and I guess I would have supported the proposal too. But, as a member of the Federal Parliament with national responsibilities, it seems to me extraordinary that anybody should seriously contemplate that proposal. The Prime Minister has made it clear that the proposal for a national income tax sharing arrangement, so-called, agreed between the Premiers and the Chief Ministers is for all practical purposes a State income tax. Therefore, the Government does not support the imposition of such a tax. The Prime Minister has made it clear—and I support him—that the Australian people do not want that burden.

For a party that is supposedly riven with division about this matter, I think my colleagues would endorse the view that when the Prime Minister made it clear to the Caucus today that the Cabinet had made a decision—I understand unanimously—to reject the proposal because it is tantamount to a State income tax, it had the unanimous support of the Caucus. It would have that support again if the matter were to come back. It is a question on which the national interest is clear and it is a question on which the Prime Minister has made the right decision. It was not an easy decision because he knew that it posed the risk of the States pulling out. Nevertheless, he made exactly the right decision.

It does not represent this so-called policy paralysis that people keep looking for to reject a bad proposal. To say, `Someone has put forward a proposal, but we don't agree with it because it's not in the national interest' is a proper decision not to do something inappropriate, and it is not something to be criticised. Far from saying that these questions of Commonwealth-State relations and Commonwealth-State financial relations cannot be discussed, the Commonwealth view remains that this issue properly should be discussed in Perth. But we make it absolutely clear—and it would be misleading not to do so—that any concept containing the elements of a State income tax is not acceptable.

If there is some manner in which we can get agreement with the States to meet their understandable concern to achieve a greater degree of certainty in the financial resources available to them and give them more certainty in Commonwealth disbursements, then let us have a look at that, but not at the price of a State income tax. That remains the Prime Minister's view; it remains the unanimous view of the Government side of the Senate and the Government side of the House of Representatives.

The Prime Minister has expressed the view that there is a strong case for the meeting in Perth proceeding even if, at the end of the day, there is no discussion on vertical fiscal imbalance. It is not our view that there should be no discussion. We are happy to have the discussion but, we are telling people in advance, not predicated on the assumption that there might be a State income tax, and I support that. It would be misleading to go on giving people the impression that we might support such a thing. We do not.

There is the prospect that there may be some fruitful discussion on the issue of financial arrangements. There will not be if the Premiers do not turn up to the meeting, but that is up to them. There is a collective responsibility for all people in government—in fact, all members of parliament in Australia—to face up to some of the other very important issues on that agenda. The Premiers themselves have said, `We want employment put on the agenda'. The Commonwealth agreed to that and now they say, `It was important a week ago, we wanted it on the agenda, but it is not important enough now. We are not going to come'.

The issue of the environment in Commonwealth-State relations is very important. There are some very important proposals for consideration in the area of education. Health and aged care also are on the agenda. An issue that has often been discussed, about which the public is clearly very concerned, is community violence and gun control. Why is it that this meeting, which is important to deal with those sorts of issues, should be held to ransom because people would like a State income tax? They would like to get their hands on some of the revenue without having to face up to any of the responsibilities. For those reasons, I think part (a) and part (b) of the amendment deserve to be rejected.

The one thing on which I agree with Senator MacGibbon is that the development and the management of relationships between the different levels of government in a federation are very complex and difficult tasks. He is absolutely correct about that. There is no perfect solution at any stage. Even when we get the best solution in any one period, it will be different again in five years, 10 years or 15 years as the nature of government evolves. I take it that that is what Senator MacGibbon was implying. I share that view. There is no perfect solution.

We have made more progress in the development of cooperative relationships between the States, the Territories and the Commonwealth recently than at any other time. There is a very substantial potential for debate to take place, and progress to be made, about reform of financial arrangements. We will not agree to part of those changed arrangements being a State income tax. If that is where the dividing line between the Commonwealth and the States, or between the Government and the Opposition, needs to be drawn, so be it. That is simply a point with which the Government will not agree.

I briefly turn to the question of Sydney Airport. This really has nothing to do with the Bill. It was dragged in because people were a bit desperate to get in and find something to say. It was dragged in off the street. The fact of the matter is that many senior members of the Government are anxious to see this project go ahead quickly. It may well be that their hope will be fulfilled in the not too distant future.

In this country, and under this Government, we continue to operate under the rule of law. The law requires certain processes to be gone through before the project can be approved. The processes should be undertaken notwithstanding that some very senior officials, very senior members, of the Opposition and the New South Wales Government would like to see things happen quickly. We do not have a dictatorship where individuals can, by decree, change laws designed to protect the interests of citizens. Those processes are being gone through; they are almost at their conclusion. When they are concluded the Government will make a decision in accordance with the law.

Part (c) of the amendment is really saying that the Government should be condemned because it has obeyed the law; it has adhered to the processes set down by the relevant legislation. I do not believe that any rational House of Parliament will condemn the Executive arm of any government for adhering to the laws which the Parliament has passed. The amendment is a joke. I recommend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record the extraordinary scene that we have just witnessed in this chamber, where the Government of the day has voted against an amendment of the Opposition calling on the Government to do precisely what is the Government's policy, and that is to expeditiously build the third runway at Sydney Airport.
