That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are debating today are the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Insurance Amendment) Bill (No.2) 1991. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 introduces a co-payment, or at least what the Government is calling a co-payment, for general practitioner consultations. Certain changes are also made to the safety net arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The Government announced these measures in the 1991-92 Budget. Indeed, Budget Paper No.9, Health Care in Australia—Directions for Reform, outlined the changes. The Medicare benefit was to be reduced from 1 November 1991 by $3.50 for out of hospital general practitioner attendance items provided to non-cardholders. From November 1992 the co-payment was to increase to a sum of $5. Where the patient was direct billed by the general practitioner, the practitioner would be permitted to charge the patient a co-payment of up to $3.50. Cardholders are exempt from the co-payment and the reduction in the Medicare benefit. Also announced were changes to the safety net arrangements. From January 1992 the safety net arrangements will change so that families count their out of pocket costs towards the safety net threshold of $246, indexed, rather than as individuals.

The latter part of the Budget proposal stayed intact, but I need not remind the Senate of what happened to the first part. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) got himself into awful trouble because of a Caucus revolt over the co-payment proposal. It was obvious to Minister Howe that Caucus was not going to accept the proposal as it stood, so he bid a hasty retreat and set up a Caucus working party to examine the Medicare changes. In his news release of 3 September 1991, the Minister outlined the conditions that would prevail on this Caucus working party committee. I wish to highlight one of them. The Minister said that one of the conditions for him to accept the proposal was that the committee would `achieve the same fiscal result for the health area as in the Budget'. The Minister kept saying that over and over again. Each time he was interviewed he stressed the fact that any proposal from the Caucus committee must meet the criterion that it would achieve the same fiscal result for the health area as in the Budget.

No-one was fooled by the Minister's setting up the working party. What hope did it have of coming up with a proposal with the objectives as outlined in the Minister's news release? Of course it had no hope at all, and did not succeed in its attempt to have the co-payment proposal thrown out. What we ended up with was a compromise that was presented to the Caucus. In fact, the compromise that the Minister came up with did not even meet the requirements that were set down for the Caucus committee. A sum of $91m was shaved from the initial Budget proposal.

The Minister only just won over his colleagues. The Minister's own Left faction voted narrowly at a heated meeting—we are led to believe a very heated meeting—to accept the compromise. Given that a Caucus defeat would have been a serious blow to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), one wonders what sorts of threats and promises were thrown at the left wing of the Labor Party to support the Minister's compromise. In fact, it was very interesting to read in the Sydney Morning Herald on 2 November the antics that the Minister's office apparently got up to. I will read from that article:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff of the Minister for Health, Mr Howe, used "heavy-handed thuggery and obstructionist tactics"—
that phrase is in quotation marks so obviously I presume the journalist is quoting from somebody—
. . . .to thwart Caucus attempts to change his planned Medicare charge, according to an internal ALP report.

PARA.TAB: The report, by Senator Rosemary Crowley, one of the back-bench members of the Caucus committee reviewing the contentious patient charges, also said the final Caucus decision to allow co-payments was heavily influenced by leadership tensions rather than the merits of the case.

SPEECH.PARA: We have said repeatedly in this chamber that the Government of this country is being affected in a detrimental way as a result of the continual leadership challenges and leadership tensions that are going on between the Prime Minister and the would-be Prime Minister, Mr Keating. The article continued:
Senator Crowley also revealed that when her committee tried to get advice from one of Medicare's architects, Dr John Deeble, the group was "accused of treachery". . .

PARA.TAB: The Caucus committee `sought information, defined the problem and set out to solve it, but it was thwarted at every turn, in particular by the refusal of the minister's office and the department to provide reliable figures to assist the committee", Senator Crowley said.

SPEECH.PARA: It was obvious that Senator Crowley and that committee were impeded in getting information. Senator Crowley turned up at the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs hearing on this Bill last Friday and had to ask for details that I would have thought she would have been given as chairman of the Caucus committee. She sat there asking the Department for details that, in order for her to have made a decision at the Caucus committee and to put forward a proposal, she should have had. Here is a backbencher in the Government unable to get information and having to go to a Senate Committee to ask for it.

PARA.TAB: That justifies what has been said in this article about all the trouble she had and how the Caucus committee was denied information it needed to make a submission. I will be interested to see whether Senator Crowley will speak in this debate. If she is not going to speak, she will be very sad that she has to sit here and watch what is going on in the chamber, given that I do not believe that the witnesses got a fair go or a fair hearing. All the Government has come up with is a compromise that is satisfactory to no-one.

As a result of the compromise, all Australians have been left with two tiers of GP schedule fees and six different levels of benefit. There are two tiers of schedule fees, depending on whether the general practitioner is vocationally registered, and three levels of benefits, depending on which billing procedure is used and whether the patient is a cardholder. Imagine the confusion that will prevail.

What astounds me is that out of all this we now have a system that will encourage bulkbilling—a root cause of the evil that is plaguing our health system. The smallest payment made will be by those patients who are bulkbilled. It will be interesting to note what sort of reaction entrepreneurial clinics will have to the charging of the patient co-payment. It is quite possible that some of these clinics will not charge the co-payment and will attempt to recover the drop in the rebate by seeing more patients for a shorter time. Surely that is not what we want.

I fail to see how this proposal will help to achieve a sustainable, equitable, efficient, universal health insurance system. It is important to note the effect that bulkbilling has on overuse and overservicing in GP consultations. In the hearing into this Bill on Friday last, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners said that there will be some evidence that relates bulkbilling to increased doctor supply. Areas that have high doctor supply have higher bulkbilling rates. I look forward with great interest to this information.

Obviously the point made by the RACGP was relevant to the supply side of GP services. It is also imperative to note the overuse that can occur on the demand side because of bulkbilling and the absence of a price signal. This is why the coalition is supportive of price signalling for general practitioner consultations. We believe that where a service is provided for free, it may—and I say `may'—be overused by some. The presence of a price signal helps to curb that overuse because patients think about the need for the service and maybe will even question the general practitioner as to the need for that service. It was interesting to note the report of the Auditor-General earlier this year, Audit report No. 32 1990-91 entitled Department of Community Services and Health—Administration of the Medicare Benefits Schedule, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the areas with the highest growth in outlays are frequently those with a high proportion of direct billing.

The Department's response to this report has been that it has been unable to duplicate the results of the survey of the Australian National Audit Office, so it has dismissed the report. I have to say that this is a fairly typical attitude to comments from the Australian National Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: In the hearing last Friday Minister Tate said:

SPEECH.PARA: The co-payment matter is only one part of a reorganisation of the provision of general practitioner medical services to the Australian population.

I have no problem with this, if only we knew what the other parts of the overall scheme included. It is patently obvious that the co-payment proposal was thrust on the Minister by the Department of Finance. The Minister for Community Services and Health then had to invent other reforms to general practice in Australia to meet the bottom line of budget savings. The problem is that no-one knows any details about the other reforms.

PARA.TAB: If what I have heard is anything to go on, the Minister will have a battle on his hands. I will be interested to see the community's response to some ideas the Minister seems to have floated; for example, drastic reductions in the numbers of young students from high school going into medical schools. Another suggestion that seems to have come from the Minister's head somewhere is that one way of reducing the number of general practitioners is to develop ways to prevent GPs practising beyond the retiring age; for example, taking away their provider number. If that is the sort of suggestion the Minister is making, I think he may need to think again.

Throughout this entire process of developing the changes that are outlined in the Bill, the Minister and his Department have neglected to undertake meaningful consultation with those members of the medical profession who have valuable first-hand experience in health care delivery. There was no consultation prior to the announcement of a co-payment in the Budget. Since then, there has been precious little. Every single group across the board—the RACGP, the AMA, the Doctors Reform Society—came into the committee hearing last week and said, `Before this decision was made, before it was announced in the Budget, there was no consultation'. I think people are reasonable and, as I said at that committee meeting, had I been Minister, I think it would have been appropriate to say, `We have problems. There is overservicing. We have what appears to be an oversupply of doctors. How are we, as a community, going to solve that?'; rather than in some dictatorial fashion telling the medical profession how it will happen. I would have thought that consultation and cooperation would have meant that not all members of the medical profession may have been happy but they may have been more likely to be on side to contribute to a solution; that is, to ensure that Australians get the best medical service as possible from their general practitioners.

I hope that would be the goal of the Government and the medical profession. But they were not given a chance to contribute, to look at the ways in which these problems could be solved. Minister Tate gave the impression that there has been fruitful and meaningful discussion between the AMA and the RACGP, but the truth is that these bodies are on the verge of war with the Government. These are the words of the National Vice-President of the AMA, not mine. In fact, there is so little agreement and consultation at the moment that the relevant bodies cannot even agree on a document that was prepared as a summary of a meeting between them.

How can these reforms of general practice in Australia lead to a better health system if the Government refuses to conduct meaningful consultation? Apparently a working party of the Australian Health Ministers Council is considering the effects of the co-payment on State hospitals. There was not even enough foresight or consultation to consider the effects of the Government's proposals on our State hospital systems. We have seen some of the State hospital systems responding to this already.

This is not the way to conduct an overhaul of general practice in Australia or of our health system. It would appear that the most fundamental problems in our health system are not going to be addressed. One of those is the fact that our system is grossly underfunded and that the private health sector has been strangled by this Government. The initial claim was that a Medicare system would be self-financing through the Medicare levy. This has never been the case. The message that must be put again and again is that the Medicare levy contributes only one-third of the funding that is outlaid on Medicare programs. The Australian community must be reminded over and over that it is a farce; it is misinformation for the Government to allow people to believe that Medicare covers the cost of health in Australia: it does not. Our health system desperately needs the private sector to be encouraged to participate and to provide additional funding that is obviously so necessary.

The second Bill we are debating today is the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. This Bill ensures that Medicare benefits are paid only where a medical practitioner provides a medical service within that practitioner's State or Territory of registration. The effect of this Bill will also be to require the repayment of Medicare benefits where a practitioner has rendered excessive services. I will restrict my comments to one area in this Bill.

The Medical Services Committee of Inquiry was established under the Health Insurance Act. It inquires into matters referred to it by the Minister, including accusations of overservicing. Changes in this Bill will mean that the Medical Services Committee of Inquiry will be able to levy a new financial penalty against medical practitioners who have rendered excessive services or have initiated excessive pathology services. This will be equal to the value of the excessive services. The Committee will also have the power to refer a medical practitioner to the medical participation review committee if it finds that he or she has rendered excessive services on two or more occasions.

My concern with this change relates to the increase in powers to be given to the Medical Services Committee of Inquiry. These changes, in effect, make the MSCI a quasi-judicial body. To this stage, the MSCI has provided counselling or caution. Given that the make-up of the MSCI consists of medical practitioners, there may be some reluctance to serve on the Committee if members are forced to impose financial penalties on their peers.

I understand the concern that there is not enough of a deterrent to overservicing, but I have some doubt as to whether this change is the most appropriate way to go. Perhaps it may have been better to reconsider the penalties the courts can impose and to ensure that all cases of suspected over-servicing are followed up which, I believe, is currently not happening.

The last matter I wish to raise relates to the ability of physiotherapists and podiatrists to perform certain X-rays. The Community Services and Health Act (No. 2) 1990 restricted the payment of Medicare rebates to X-ray referrals from general practitioners, dentists and chiropractors. Prior to the passing of the legislation, physiotherapists were responsible for ordering X-rays for their patients. The majority of physiotherapists in private practice use X-rays as an integral part of diagnosis and patient care. However, since 1 May physiotherapists have been restricted in their ability to order X-rays. A doctor's referral is now needed for R-type X-rays for which a Medicare benefit is payable.

I do not think I would be misleading the Senate to say that I have taught almost 1,000—if not over the thousand mark—physiotherapists, and honourable senators can imagine how they beat a hasty path to my door to discuss this issue with me. When I went through it and discovered that it was really an oversight that physiotherapists had been omitted from this clause in the Bill and that general practitioners, dentists and chiropractors had been included, I wrote to the Minister asking him to address the issue. I am pleased to hear that the Minister has acceded to the request and will be making an amendment to legislation this session to allow physiotherapists to refer for R-type X-rays of the spine and pelvic area. I do not know whether, without that pushing, it would have been done as quickly as, hopefully, it will be done.

Podiatrists have been restricted in their ability to refer directly for R-type X-rays of the lower leg, ankle and foot. I have not taught thousands of podiatrists, but I have taught a large number of them. Over the past 10 years there have been significant changes in the education of podiatrists in Australia. In view of the procedures they perform, it would benefit them to have access to the information which is available from the X-rays. Referral may not be crucial if the patient wishes to claim the higher R-type rebate.

We have been suggesting that the podiatrists be included in this clause to enable them to refer for R-type X-rays. I was delighted to learn that Minister Howe has agreed to support an amendment to be moved by the shadow Minister for health, Dr Bob Woods, to legislation currently before the House to allow podiatrists to refer patients directly for R-type X-rays of the lower leg, ankle and foot. In conclusion, I indicate that the coalition will be supporting the legislation that is before us this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be directing my remarks at the first of these two Bills—the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991—which the Australian Democrats will be opposing. We will be supporting the second one—the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991.

PARA.TAB: I know that many Government senators share the Democrats' concerns and no doubt many of them have fought very hard in Caucus to have the Government abandon this move to enforce a co-payment. I call upon those honourable senators to demonstrate their commitment to the principles of Medicare and to the 70 per cent of Australians who support the Medicare system by voting against this Bill tonight. To those honourable senators I say that I do appreciate that they are bound by Cabinet rulings and then, of course, tied by Caucus solidarity, as they call it. But I ask them, on this issue, what value is there in permitting themselves to be hamstrung by this process when it means a failure on their part to demonstrate the same solidarity with the vast majority of Australians who do not want to see further undermining of Medicare, and who believe that this is very much a misguided effort on behalf of the Government to address problems within our medical system that we do acknowledge exist.

Thousands upon thousands of their constituents out there are wondering just how far the Labor Party can sell out its principles before some Government members crack and actually dare to vote against the tyranny of Cabinet and, I guess, put on record the fact that they really are listening to their constituencies. I would argue that many members of the Labor Party are now so patently out of touch with the needs and aspirations of ordinary Australians that it is only a matter of time before we see what is happening in some State parliaments, where independent members are becoming quite common.

Of course, Medicare has never been very popular with some—indeed, not popular at all with many members of the Opposition. It has also not been very popular with some doctors—particularly members of the AMA. However, its popularity with the public continues to grow. Last year's ANOP survey found that about seven in 10 Australians—71 per cent—were in favour of Medicare and just over two in 10 Australians, or 22 per cent, were opposed to it. Not surprisingly, support for Medicare is higher amongst those who rely on Medicare—indeed, it is very high at 85 per cent. But, at 60 per cent, support is still high among those who carry private health cover. As ANOP observed:

SPEECH.PARA: The clear finding. . . is that despite these differences, the clear majority in all groups is in favour of Medicare.
ANOP went on to observe:
Overall, the 1990 study has confirmed that the principles of Medicare are now widely accepted and the main features of the Medicare program have solid community support.

It is hard to think of any other government or, indeed, private program that has such widespread support. One really has to ask why the Government is dismantling one of the most popular projects for which it is responsible. Medicare has, by and large, achieved what it was set up to do. Despite the problems, it has provided Australians with equitable access to relatively cheap health care.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to move on to look at some of the costs. In 1988-89, $29.5 billion was spent on health care in Australia. Of that, some $6 billion—about one-fifth—came from direct out of pocket payments by individuals. The remainder of the expenditure comes from the Commonwealth Government—via the Medicare levy and taxation—State and local governments, and workers and motor vehicle accident compensation funds.

In the case of expenditure by individuals, the analysis of the health expenditure survey and Medicare undertaken by the national health strategy indicates that the provision of free services substantially protects low income households from the cost of basic health care—that is, GP services, hospital care and prescriptions. This protection primarily occurs through the bulkbilling mechanism. The national health strategy paper, Spending on Health, came up with the very important conclusion that free, or certainly low cost, basic health care protects two kinds of vulnerable people: firstly, those on low incomes, for whom even small out of pocket costs are too much and would deter them from seeing doctors when they need to; and, secondly, the high users. Into that group fall people with disabilities and the chronically ill who would otherwise have substantial out-of-pocket costs.

Australians understand that they do not receive their health care for nothing. They are quite well aware that they pay for it via the Medicare levy and through taxation. I believe the widespread support for Medicare by the Australian community demonstrates that Australians are generally willing—if not pleased—to pay for a health care system which protects the two kinds of people I have just talked about.

Australians are well aware of the shambles that masquerades as a health care system in the United States, and no-one wants to go down that track. They do not want to have a system where access to basic essential services is denied to so many. Indeed, it is most ironic that, at a time when many in the United States are calling for some commitment to universal public health care to overcome the problems of a private system, we have the Parliament in this country appearing to be moving in the opposite direction.

The Government agrees that Medicare has largely been successful in keeping health costs down. In its own Budget Paper—Budget Related Paper No. 9—it states that it believes that Medicare has been a successful program. Health care costs in this country have been fairly constant—around 8 per cent of GDP—for quite some time, about 14 years. Although others will disagree, this is not an astronomically high proportion of GDP if we accept the desirability of meeting social objectives.

The Australian Democrats see the provision of basic health care as a desirable social and economic objective. Although we see considerable room for improvement in the delivery of health care services, we do not consider 8 per cent of GDP too high an amount for total expenditure. This is not to deny that there is a need to rein in some areas of health expenditure. But we need to be clear that Medicare has enabled better control of the growth of health care expenditure. Overseas evidence—again we can refer to the United States—indicates that those countries where public health insurance plays a key role have been the most successful in controlling total health expenditure.

I now want to look at why we need a co-payment. After sitting through Friday's hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I find it very difficult to work out exactly why it is that we need this co-payment. There is not a great deal of Australian research, data or information about the distribution or impact of health costs. But what evidence there is goes against the Government's assertions. Indeed, I believe that the Government is doing its best to ignore the evidence that exists. The evidence that I believe it is ignoring includes quite unique data being collected by the national health strategy, an expensive exercise which the Government appears hell-bent on pre-empting.

Senator Peter Walsh brought home this fact in this chamber last month when he asked for some pretty basic data about the per capita growth in GP attendance over the past 11 years, with particular reference to the utilisation by cardholders versus non-cardholders. One would presume that this would have been the type of information on which the Government was basing its decisions. However, we find that was not the case.

Senator Tate, in his response to Senator Walsh, admitted that data is not available on the utilisation of services by cardholders as distinct from non-cardholders, although estimates were made as part of the decision-making. I argue that is not very reassuring when we are talking about such a major change. This is indeed a very major change in the Medicare scheme which could have significant effects on the health of the community. Senator Tate also had to point out that there had been a decline in the number of visits to GPs on a per capita basis over the last year.

There is also evidence from the national health strategy that co-payment may have a small effect on demand but will establish a framework for an uncontrolled increase in costs. As Professor Geoff Richardson, the Director of the National Centre for Health Program Evaluation at Monash University, has noted, the introduction of the co-payment potentially moves us towards a situation of cost shifting rather than cost control.

Professor Richardson's paper for the national health strategy entitled The Effects of Consumer Co-Payments in Medical Care is really the first comprehensive survey of this issue carried out in this country. He found that the introduction of a co-payment is likely to cause a one-off reduction in the base level of demand but that the supply side response from the medical profession would probably result in an offset of this demand by around 50 per cent. In other words, if we do not tackle the supply side of the health services equation, the effect of the co-payment on the overall level of demand is likely to be modest. So one wonders what the Government figures about the savings from this measure are really based on.

But the real problem is that co-payment sets up a structure under which a number of problems may arise. I will just go through three of them. The available evidence suggests that increased co-payments result in higher medical incomes in exchange for less output. Co-payments open up the prospect of unrestrained inflation. Although this may not occur in Australia, it certainly has elsewhere. Co-payments have a greater impact on low income people, especially their children, and people with poorer health. These are the ones most likely to suffer.

I want to look at co-payment as a price signal, which Senator Patterson has already dealt with. The Government and the Opposition argue that co-payment operates as a price signal. It is one of the rationalists' favourite maxims that offering a free service ensures the service will be overused and abused. Certainly there are many areas where this is the case, but I would argue very strongly that this does not apply to the health system and the delivery of health services.
Firstly, while there is undoubtedly overservicing in the health area, it is not correct to blithely put it down to overusage by patients. Indeed, as Professor Richardson notes in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: For most categories of the medical workforce there appears to be a consensus that there is a problem of excess supply of doctors and not an excess demand.

I would argue that sending out a price signal does absolutely nothing to tackle this problem. A price signal also represents a determination to impose free market principles and mechanisms on a system that will not respond to them for a variety of reasons. It is basically a misunderstanding about the functioning of the health system and of health economics. The kindest interpretation is that it possibly is a genuine misunderstanding coming from a genuinely held ideological viewpoint and a commitment to competition. But there are many who push this view who are quite clearly doing so for their own vested financial interests.

PARA.TAB: The evidence here and overseas is clear: market signals are undermined by the distinctive nature of the health system. A number of features of the health system make free market logic unconvincing in this context. Firstly, the existence of insurance acts to minimise price signals. Even if we were to abandon Medicare altogether and move to a totally private insurance system, we would still have this operating.

Secondly, there is an imbalance in the amount and nature of information available to patients and service providers. In other words, it is virtually impossible for consumers of health services to exercise a free choice in the health market because genuine independent evaluation about the benefit obtained by the product is virtually impossible.

Thirdly, the structure of the health market undermines market mechanisms. There is restrictive entry for service providers and no alternative source of supply for many. The basis of competition can become higher levels of service rather than a more effective or efficient service. Again, price signals do not address this.

Finally, the concept of health care is overlaid with social justice objectives that do not necessarily equate with marketplace objectives. In other words, economic efficiency is not necessarily the goal that a community is aiming for in health care. Indeed, most communities, especially those in the developed world, aim for the provision of basic health care for all members of the community.

There are also economic merits in these sorts of objectives. For example, presumably a healthy work force will be more productive than an unhealthy one, and so on. But these kinds of merits are too often overlooked in the pursuit of what I could perhaps call the more obvious economic goals. We are talking there about more savings and expenditure reductions. So the concept of a co-payment as a price signal is not only an invalid one, given other factors that work in any health care system, but it can also serve to undermine what a community may well consider to be desirable outcomes in the delivery of health services.

I would now like to look at bulkbilling. I want to say a few words about this because, again, I believe that the evidence about its role in our health system shows up pretty clearly that a lot of nonsense is often talked about it. Despite assertions to the contrary from some quarters in the Opposition and the medical profession, bulkbilling does not increase health expenditure in the medical profession. The national health strategy data suggests that the major impact of bulkbilling is an increase in the number of patients seen by a GP, not an increase in the fees per GP.

Bulkbilling also represents a powerful competitive tool. Although there is contradictory evidence around about whether patients choose GPs according to whether they bulkbill, it seems that GPs who bulkbill generally attract more patients and, therefore, even higher incomes—possibly because bulkbilling GPs charge their patients less. For example, in 1990-91, doctors who bulkbilled charged, on average, 8 per cent less than doctors who did not.

There appears to be validity in the claim that some of these doctors do give less time per patient, but patients apparently do not always mind, because they continue to use bulkbilled services. There is anecdotal evidence to suggest that many patients, in fact, prefer less time with their doctor as long as they feel that their particular problem—their particular reason for going to the GP—has been satisfactorily resolved.

Of course, there are potential problems with the reduced time per consultation, but what is clear is that bulkbilling operates as an effective price competition which actually exerts downward pressure on GPs' fees. It would stop the inflation that would occur if these measures that the Government is taking do, indeed, undermine the bulkbilling system. All the available evidence suggests that, if we do away with bulkbilling, health care costs will escalate and the poor and less well off will pay more for their health care. The Australian Democrats have long been supporters of bulkbilling and we believe that this co-payment heralds its demise, to the detriment of our system of health care generally and low-income earners in particular.

I guess we could have a dozen different views on the effects of the co-payment, depending on whom one speaks to. However, despite what the Government would like us to think, it really does not have much of a clue about the potential effects of the co-payment. It became very clear to me, from listening to all the witnesses in the Senate Committee hearing on Friday, that they are fairly united in this. I would argue that the Government really is very much in the dark about what exactly will happen and what the effects of the co-payment will be.

Aside from the data collected by the national health strategy which, as I have already noted, the Government is now largely ignoring, the Government really has no idea at all where this move will take it. Basically, the Government is conducting a massive experiment with no idea of what the eventual outcome will be. It is not certain that demand will drop or, if it does, whether this will result in detrimental effects on low income earners and their children.It has no idea of how many doctors will relinquish bulkbilling, how many will absorb it and how many will take the additional charge and cover it internally by collecting it from their patients. Indeed, there are a variety of different opinions as to how doctors are going to work around it. Therefore, the Government has absolutely no idea how the co-payment will impact upon bulkbilling and whether a significant reduction in the numbers of doctors who are bulkbilling will result in a hike in GPs' fees or increased health care costs overall.

The Government also has no idea about the potential impact on other areas of the health system. For example, on Friday at the Senate committee hearing, I referred to the community health centres and public hospitals. Mr Ian Lennie, executive officer of the Australian Community Health Association, urged the Committee to recommend that salaried bulkbilling practices be exempt from the co-payment as the revenue lost to centres through the co-payment would seriously affect their ability to deliver services. Mr Lennie explained that centres would come under pressure to pass on the charge to their clients, many of whom are already on low incomes and this may, indeed, deter many clients.

Similarly, the submission from the Australian Hospitals Association raised questions about the impact of the co-payment on hospital outpatient and casualty services. In his evidence to the Senate Committee, Mr Ian McNeil, First Assistant Secretary to the health care access division of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, admitted that the effect of the co-payment on outpatient services was `debatable'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage there is no way of knowing whether it will have a significant impact or not.

That is very reassuring! So why is all this being done? What are the problems with our health care system? I suggest that they are some or all of the following: increasing costs of medical technology; the escalating use of pathology and radiology services; waiting lists in public hospitals; an ageing population which is putting demand on a variety of services and is increasing the share of the health budget; and an oversupply of doctors but, at the same time, the inadequate distribution of doctors so that some areas—particularly the outer metropolitan areas of our larger cities and rural areas—do not have even the basic number of medical practitioners required.

PARA.TAB: These problems certainly need fixing; I do not deny that. However, the Democrats strongly oppose the introduction of the co-payment as the means of fixing any of these problems. It will not solve them. As one example, let us look at the supply of doctors. There is agreement that there is an oversupply of doctors. As the Department pointed out to the Senate Committee, doctor numbers have been growing. However, it is difficult to pin down the impact of this growth in relation to health costs. Certainly, medical service use per person is increasing but, as I noted earlier, there is some uncertainty about how this relates to per capita visits to GPs.

If there continues to be an increase in such visits, it is quite possible that this will be due to a reduction in the amount of time people spend in hospital and the fact that we are now making greater efforts to minimise the number of elderly and disabled people in our community who need access to hospital and nursing home services. Thus, it is entirely possible that an increase in visits to GPs will be offset by savings in other areas, such as in our nursing homes and hospitals. We must not forget the other facets of improved community access and well-being for those people who do not want to spend time in nursing homes and hospitals. The issue of oversupply of doctors is also complicated by the fact that there is a shortage of practitioners in rural and remote areas, as I mentioned.

I argue that the simple fact is that the Government has basically opted out of looking seriously at the problems in the health care system. Its own national health strategy has already made many significant suggestions about structural reform which could address many of these problems, as well as improve the efficiency and effectiveness of health service delivery in this country.

As for the co-payment, make no mistake about it, it is basically a cost saving exercise. The Government, in particular the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), has talked about it being part of some sort of remarkable and miraculous reorganisation of the provision of general practitioner services, but as the co-payment is the only bit of this so-called reorganisation we have seen, we cannot comment on what the total package is going to be. We have seen no direct evidence of the Government tackling the supply side of the health service equation and this begs the question: if the Government is really serious about re-organisation that addresses both demand and supply, why not wait until it has the full package in place and then introduce all the measures together? At least we would then possibly be in a better position to judge the likely effects of this move on the health system.

We all know why this has not occurred—because, basically, Brian Howe wanted extra dollars to fund his better cities program and, of course, the Department of Finance is always there ready and willing to carve up Medicare. It has apparently been looking at that as a possibility for quite some time. It provided Minister Howe with all the evidence he needed, and I would argue that it is very contrary evidence to all the existing evidence that we have been through with regard to the health system. The Department of Finance gave the Minister the opportunity to claim the extra funds by attacking the public health insurance system.

It says nothing for Caucus, despite the determined efforts of some members—which I recognise—that it ultimately let him get away with it. I again call on those honourable senators who are opposed to the co-payment to think about the 70 per cent of Australians who approve of the Medicare system. I ask them to join with the Democrats in opposing this Bill. If they do not, the situation will be, as Diedre Wicks and Roy Green observed in the Sunday Age on 13 October:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's Caucus may have saved the Government, but nothing will now save Medicare.

In summary, the Democrats will be voting against the second reading of the Health Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. We will not be opposing the Health Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1991.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8.00 p m.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator WALTERS (Tasmania) (8.00 p.m.)—The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 relate primarily to Budget decisions on the co-payment of the supposed $3.50 to be paid by patients for consultations with their general practitioner. At least, that is what the Budget decision was. Medicare was never going to work. This decision of the Government has at least acknowledged that Medicare has now come to an end. One of the primary components of Medicare was bulkbilling. This legislation has effectively done away with bulkbilling. I am not the only person to have said that. The AMA, the Royal College of General Practitioners, the Doctors Reform Society and community groups have all said that this legislation has effectively done away with Medicare. What a shemozzle it has been.

PARA.TAB: The Government brought down the Budget. We all know that every government says that its Budget is sacrosanct. No Opposition—even the Labor Government when it was in Opposition—likes to interfere with a government's Budget Bills. Indeed, that has often been described as denying Supply or interfering with the outcome of the Budget. While the Opposition goes along with the Government's decision on the Budget, what does its own back bench decide to do? I have been here long enough to know that when a Budget is given to the party room it is supposed to be a fait accompli—not so with this Government. For the first time that I can remember the back bench rolled the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Cabinet. The back bench decided that it did not want to have that co-payment; that it wanted Medicare, despite all its faults, to remain unscathed.

The Prime Minister and, indeed, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) virtually put their jobs on the line and said, `Okay, you can make some changes but we need the same outcome financially'. We are all well aware that that, of course, did not happen. The Government is now well down the drain on its Budget figures.

The Government decided to set up a back bench committee to come up with an alternative suggestion. A lot relied on the present fight going on between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. That, of course, was drawn into the Caucus fight that ensued after the Budget decision was made public. The end result is a halfway house—a hotchpotch of the worst of all evils.

We now have the patient co-payment of $2.50. If the general practitioner decides to bulkbill, the patient will pay $2.50; if the general practitioner does not bulkbill, the patient will pay $3.50. Because the back bench decided against the Government's Budget statement—it knew better and wanted to keep encouraging doctors to bulkbill—it decided, in its wisdom, to give the doctors a dollar to continue bulkbilling. I have never heard of anything so stupid. The Cabinet decided to discourage bulkbilling and, indeed, to get rid of it, insisting upon a patient co-payment. Then Cabinet succumbed to the back bench and said, `But we want to encourage doctors to bulkbill so we will give them a dollar if they continue to bulkbill'. Is it any surprise that the public wonders what on earth has happened to this Government? The Government's lack of credibility has never been as great as it is at the moment.

As I said, we have the situation where if a doctor bulkbills he gets a whole dollar from the Government to do so. Can honourable senators imagine the administrative costs of that? The doctor gets a whole dollar from the Government; the patient pays him $2.50, so bulkbilling is out. If the doctor does not bulkbill, the patient pays an additional $3.50 because the rebate that the patient gets back for a consultation fee is reduced by $3.50.

That was not all that this wonderful back bench committee looked at and came up with. It said, `Let's bring forward $12m to be spent in the next financial year'—that is, the financial year 1992-93—`to this financial year, 1991-92. There will be no alterations in the appropriations; nothing will be needed; we'll get it out of the Minister for Finance's slush fund. We don't want to have to admit that there were alterations; we'll just grab a bit out of the Minister for Finance's slush fund'. Of course, we all know that is not the usual procedure. Indeed, when the Budget comes down we have appropriations. Appropriations are accurately passed in this place, according to the decision of the government of the day.

Everyone was so confused by this stage—mainly the Government—that the Government welcomed the setting up of the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs to sort out the mess. The AMA, the Royal College of General Practitioners, the Doctors Reform Society and a community forum appeared before the Committee to explain their concerns in regard to this legislation. All of those groups said that the Government had broken its promise on consultation. Sometime ago the Government had said to the medical practitioners and the medical industry, `We promise that we will consult with you if we are going to alter anything substantially'. It could hardly be said that this is not a substantial alteration. Indeed, all groups complained bitterly to the Committee last Friday—my colleagues have referred to it—that there was no consultation by the Government and that the Government had once again broken its promise. The Government's excuse of course is, `We could not tell you all about it because it was a Budget decision'.

I might add that we have more legislation coming up on pathology. The Government certainly consulted with the pathologists. I wonder why! The Government had its fingers burnt by the pathologists on a previous occasion. The pathologists took the Government to the High Court and won. The Government does not fool around with the pathologists any more. The Government consults with the pathologists. It is time that the AMA and the Royal College of General Practitioners decided to pull the same stunt and make the Government respectful of its promises. As I said, the basic tenet of Medicare, bulkbilling, has been abolished. My notes for my speech say, `Medicare—bulkbilling—gone'.
Senator Lees, on behalf of the Democrats, stated that bulkbilling does not make any difference to the number of medical services.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me once again—because I have done so on several occasions—give a simple explanation of how bulkbilling does make a difference. I would like Senator Lees, who is in the chamber, to listen to this example. I know that I have done this before but each year I bring the figures up to date because it is interesting to see how they climb. In New South Wales, with entrepreneurial clinics all over the place—and I might add that, by allowing bulkbilling, the Government encouraged their establishment—76.1 per cent of GP attendances are bulkbilled.

PARA.TAB: In Tasmania, where general practitioners and the medical profession do not allow entrepreneurial clinics—they ran them out of town when they tried last time—58.7 per cent of general practitioners visits are bulkbilled. So in New South Wales the figure is 76.1 per cent and in Tasmania 58.7 per cent. The cost per head for Medicare bulkbilling—man, woman and child—of that 76.1 per cent in New South Wales is $105.20; in Tasmania, with 58.7 per cent bulkbilling, it is only $90.40 per head.

I really do not believe that Senator Lees can claim that this does not indicate that all of these entrepreneurial clinics have excess servicing. Senator Tate will be aware of how we fought this in Tasmania. Patients attending entrepreneurial clinics were sent to other GPs for a second opinion, for X-rays, for pathology and for other examinations. All of these services were bulkbilled. Nobody can possibly say—and I have just given the figures—that such a practice does not encourage bulkbilling and overservicing.

Let me get back to the figures. As I said, the cost per head in New South Wales is $105.20 and in Tasmania $90.40. If, with our small population in Tasmania, there were as many bulkbilling attendances as there were in New South Wales—in other words, if it were 76.1 per cent in Tasmania—there would be an additional cost of $6.8m to Medicare. That is in a State with a small population of 400,000. If one looks at the figures Australia-wide, one cannot help but come to the conclusion that the Government is right—that there is a blow-out in Medicare costs. If one allows bulkbilling for everyone and if entrepreneurial clinics continue to operate as they have, the taxes that this Government has to raise will continue to escalate as they have ever since it has been in power.

The Government has now abolished bulkbilling. There is now to be a co-payment by the patient; that is, the patient must now pay part of that fee. But the Government has denied the patient the option of private insurance. It will not permit private insurance for doctors' consultations and for surgery. It has forced patients to pay these costs out of their own pocket. This is the only area in Australia in which the Government has decided that people cannot insure. One can insure ones house or car. One can insure against death and sickness. But one cannot insure against having to see a doctor. The lack of civil liberties in this area is quite appalling.

We now come to the extra $12m that the Government back bench has decided in its wisdom should be brought forward. I asked Senator Tate at a Friday meeting whether he could explain some of these so-called future reforms to the funding of general practice. When I asked him what was meant by the statement `Information technology could substantially enhance diagnostic and patient education roles of GPs', he said, `It's all English'. I said, `Okay, but what does it actually mean?'. He ended up by saying, `I don't know; it all depends. What they are going to have to do is talk about it. But I don't know how it is going to help patient education roles. Don't ask me; I am only the Minister'. That is what he was indicating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered endlessly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he answered endlessly by saying, `I don't know. It all depends on the negotiations that have got to take place between the general practitioners, the AMA and the Government. And I've got no idea what it is all about really because the negotiations have not got under way yet'. He may just as well have said, `Senator, your guess is as good as mine'.

PARA.TAB: He also said that the negotiations had all been very amicable. But, as he was saying that, representatives of both the College of General Practitioners and the AMA sitting behind him were shaking their heads vigorously. I said to the Minister, `You can't see behind you but representatives of the AMA and the College are shaking their heads and saying that it was not amicable and that they had not come to an agreement'. Let us have a look at some of those reforms. The first is the use of practice grants to complement fee for service reimbursement. I believe that this is how the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, wants it to work: the Government will say to a group of three or four general practitioners, `Give up your fee for service and we will give you a grant'. I might be a bit long in the tooth but to me that means—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not true.

—Senator Kemp will agree with me that that means nationalisation. There is no way that anyone who is on the government payroll is not nationalised. The next proposed reform is the trialing of the use of practice budgets. When I got to that I asked the Minister what on earth that meant, and he said, `Well, I don't know'. If the Minister does not know what a budget is, I do. A budget means one works to one's budget and one does not go over the budget. Will the Government push for non-accredited general practices to have less of a reimbursement, less of a rebate, than the accredited general practices? I can only see that as the next step. I can only foresee the Government treating accreditation as it has vocational registration. We will have to wait and see just what the Government does in that regard.

We then come to the supply and distribution of medical practices. As I said a little while ago, just think of the pharmacists, because that is the direction in which we are going. According to the Government, pharmacists were in oversupply. The Government did not like the distribution of pharmacists. It said that all that oversupply and maldistribution created terrible problems of overservicing—even though of course the pharmacists do not write the prescriptions. I say to the doctors, `Beware! Oversupply and maldistribution, according to the Government's guidelines, means the same for the doctors as it has for the pharmacists'. The medical profession should think of that before it enters into negotiations with the Government, because that is what the Government has in store for it.

The Minister said, `For the sake of social justice, we must continue to take in overseas doctors. While we may cut those a bit, we are also going to cut our own medical students here in Australia and not allow as many to become medical practitioners'. The last topic for discussion is information technology. The document circulated by the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: Information technology could substantially enhance diagnostic and patient education roles of GPs. . .

I stop there. The Minister told me this could assist general practitioners considerably. All the practitioner will need to do is get out the word processor or computer and type up the symptoms and out will come the diagnosis. The doctor will just say, `Give me your symptoms', he or she will type them up, hand the patient the sheet of paper and the patient will know just what the illness is. PARA.TAB: For the information of the Minister—I know he does not have much medical knowledge; I am not blaming him for that, he is first rate at law—every patient's body reacts differently to situations. I can remember when I was having my children. I would complain bitterly about something to my husband and he would just wipe me by saying, `It's all right, they are perfectly natural, some do and some don't'. That, quite frankly, is true. I could be pregnant; my next door neighbour could be pregnant. We would have totally different symptoms, because some do and some do not. Symptoms vary so much that the doctor cannot just type them into a computer and have it spit out a diagnosis.
Then we come to patient education. Could the Minister please tell me how this information technology will assist patient education in the GP's surgery. I am most interested. The circular continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as well as improving the business management of practices.

That is the only aspect I understand fully. If a general practitioner has his computer, it will improve his business practice—not that many general practitioners are good businessmen; indeed, far from it. Does that mean that the Government will give the doctors computers? If the Government is to subsidise them and give them computers, what does it want back? What the Government wants back, of course, is data on patients. That is what it gets back from the pharmacists and that is what it will want from the general practitioners. The general practitioners will have those little black boxes that the pharmacists have.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to the basics. The pharmacists have been nationalised; they can no longer set up where they want to; and they can no longer operate as they wish. TALK.START.PARA: —That was not vintage Senator Walters; that was beyond vintage. It was into a new realm. `Extraordinary' might be the kindest way I can describe her comments. —Indeed, I think she is now protesting again that that is a good idea. —You thought it.
—The Minister says that I thought it. I did not think it.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Secondly, Senator Walters suggests that one cannot insure about going to the doctor, which is to convey a basic misunderstanding of what Medicare is. If it is nothing else, it is an insurance scheme that covers people up to the rebate for the cost of going to the doctor. If that is not Senator Walters's agreed position, she does no more than confirm my earlier remarks—that it is beyond her to understand them. The Senate needs to know—
—Some insurance scheme!

—That is a good interjection because 70 per cent of Australians say indeed it is some insurance scheme; they like it very much indeed and so do, of course, many doctors. TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let us remind ourselves again that something like 70 per cent of Australians in a very recent poll—within the last 12 months—admit that they are in favour of Medicare. Something like the same percentage on average of general practitioners across the country use bulkbilling. So we have a fair understanding and evidence from the way doctors behave that bulkbilling under Medicare—the umbrella under which bulkbilling is possible—has been widely accepted by the profession.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters took us through the difference between New South Wales figures and Tasmanian figures and even boasted that she, we, they, had campaigned against bulkbillers in Tasmania. That is a bit interesting because, ultimately, the decision to bulkbill is one that resides with the medical practitioner, unfortunately not with the patient, to make a choice.

Many doctors take account of a patient's preference and have moved to bulkbilling, although it is also true that there are not so many doctors who bulkbill 100 per cent of their patients. About 80 per cent of doctors only bulkbill in part. Something like 20 per cent to 22 per cent of general practitioners bulkbill above 80 per cent—80 per cent to 100 per cent of the people who come to see them.

It is also true that the majority of doctors in this country bulkbill age pensioners. While there are some doctors who actually accept a pay doctor cheque, the majority of doctors have accepted bulkbilling of age pensioners, by way of consideration and care for pensioners that they not be disadvantaged or troubled by the cost of finding the money to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they should.
—So they used to—always have done.
—When they did not bulkbill they treated them for nothing.

—I find it interesting to hear the clucking of sympathy to this point of view from those opposite! If it is all right to bulkbill age pensioners out of some understanding of so they should, what makes it justifiable in the case of age pensioners but not in the case of anyone else in the community? Apparently when one moves beyond pensioners and practices exactly the same way of collecting the payment for a medical service, one is suddenly being run amuck by the `mad Labor Government'. That is in quotes and is not my view of this Labor Government. It is a measure of the Opposition's assessment and it is a very insufficient one. It fails to recognise—and Senator Walters's whole speech failed to recognise—that we in this country are facing an overservicing of patients by an oversupply of doctors, paid for by a fee-for-service, uncapped provision, providing in the end either a holding level, holding steady, or falling income for general practitioners.

PARA.TAB: If one is concerned at all about the quality of general practice and a fair return to the general practitioners of this country for the very splendid service the majority of them provide, one would have to ask oneself some very serious questions of how best to provide for patients so that they are not disadvantaged in going to the doctor by having to find the money and for the general practitioners so that they get a reasonable return for the imperative service that they provide. That is what this Government is addressing. It is concerned to see that the quality general practice is promoted.

It is on the record—I do not have here to wave about the lengthy quotes from the AMA and a number of places—that there is an oversupply of doctors in this country practising in general practice. The profession admits it and the College of General Practitioners admits it. The Government knows it and is trying to address it. It is also perfectly prepared to address the question of continuing quality care in general practice and changing the parameters so that that continuing quality of care can be promoted and developed further.

A year or so ago I chaired the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance inquiring into vocational registration of general practitioners. The Committee produced a report that affirmed vocational registration and accepted it as the first of many steps that this Government has introduced and will introduce to maintain quality general practice—to support the claims of the College of General Practitioners, and even the AMA, for the importance of postgraduate and special to general practice training for general practitioners. The Government recognises the need for quality and continuing education; the medical profession recognises it; and the Government recognises that it should be acknowledged by increased remuneration. That is all undeniable. The record stands: that has been the practice of this Government.

If Senator Walters cannot understand what is to be the final definitions of practice grants or the parameters of quality care into the future, when the Minister says to her that the final details of that are to be negotiated between the profession and the Government, as I say, that is a measure of Senator Walters's limitations and no discrediting of the Minister.

I was tempted to take points of orders against Senator Walters for her fairly outrageous dealing in a very, I think, unkind way with the best that the Minister offered in the hearing of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs the other day. I was present for much of the hearing. After listening to Senator Walters today, one could not have concluded that the Minister had goodwill and was trying to answer her questions. But the Minister was; he did, and it was mischievous of Senator Walters to suggest otherwise. The Government is also clear—it has already established the discussions with the AMA and the College of General Practitioners—on determining the committees, the structures and the context of those negotiating teams between the profession and—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Is Senator Walters saying that is not true to me?
—I sure am.
—What does that mean—that I am a liar?
—It means that you're misinformed.
—Does it? It is getting very close to: what I am not allowed to say to Senator Walters she is apparently free to say to me. I have the documentation here.
—Diddums!

—Do not diddums me or you will be seen in the corridor afterwards! That is what those opposite wanted so I thought I would give it to them a little bit—it is called a tickle-up. I have the documents here—and I am not about to give them to Senator Walters—describing the proposals for negotiation. The Minister says there will be negotiation, the Department says there will be negotiation, yet Senator Walters calls us liars. I think Senator Walters is absolutely disgraceful, but there is little we can do about such a disgraceful performance. Senator Walters is uncivil.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Walters should know, it takes time to negotiate with the medical profession. The profession has its own character and it cannot be rushed. As Senator Walters properly points out, if the negotiations go too fast, sometimes the medical profession gets very cross and goes away: witness the AMA, which has not been negotiating with the Government on medical benefit schedule fees for quite some time.

The other suggestion from Senator Walters was that if the medical profession were to get as tough as the pharmacists did with this Government and took it to court this Government may behave differently. I refer Senator Walters to Dr Bruce Shepherd's hairy-chested claims shortly after this Budget was introduced that he would go to the High Court. That hit the front page of many newspapers. I notice that he is now beating a retreat from that position. I am not sure whether he had advice, but nothing the Government does will give him his day in court. Perhaps he thought the cost was not worth it. The Government knows where it stands vis-a-vis the medical profession, and I think Dr Shepherd has learnt, too, that it is not a good idea to rush to headlines, boasting that one will do things which one subsequently discovers one does not want to or cannot do.

The Government is at pains to negotiate with the medical profession. It is committed to quality general practice; it is committed to continuing care; and it is committed, on behalf of all of the people in this country, to restraining the total outlays of health. For the past eight years, the cost of health in this country has been just below eight per cent of GDP, and this year it is projected to be just above it.

That stands in great contrast to the cost of health care in the United States of America where it is resting at 12 per cent. I am advised that it will go above that. If one looks at the number of Americans who do not have access to any kind of medical insurance and whose quality of health care is very poor, one would acknowledge how good the system is in Australia. When I visited Washington and saw senior health officials in the health department, their comment to me was, `What is Australia doing visiting America? America should go to Australia to find a preferred way of providing good quality affordable health care for its people'.

There are now considerable responses to those pressures emerging in America—Senator Walters would be shocked—where in some of the states fixed fees are being negotiated for the general practitioners. That is because that country recognises, as this country has known for a long time, that one cannot have an unlimited cost to the provision of health care. It does not do the profession any good; it does not do the economics of the country any good; and it does not necessarily assist the patients. It is the balance this country and this Government has achieved that ought to be earning Senator Walters's plaudits.

Senator Patterson asked me earlier what I thought about the proposed changes to the legislation. Senator Patterson knows very well what I think about those changes. I fought very strenuously not to see them introduced. They are now part of the proposed legislation, and here I stand supporting them. That is a matter of fact. That is as a result of being a member of the Labor Caucus and the Labor Government. I have no trouble at all with that.

My question today to the Minister, Senator Tate, shows that I am very interested in the processes that will be set up by the Government to monitor the impacts of these changes. I am concerned to see how the changes come into effect and how they may fall—whether there will be a significant shift away from bulkbilling; whether there will be a maintenance of bulkbilling; whether in fact patients will start advising that they cannot afford to see the doctor because of the costs; or whether the changes in the safety net will provide the sort of assurance and fallback for those patients who may have thought they were troubled. The modification of the safety net under this legislation is something about which we should be reminding our constituents.

We should be reminding the people of Australia that the safety net in Medicare has changed. It has gone to a sum of $246 for a family. Once the people who constitute a family register with the Health Insurance Commission and once the payments by the patient of any scheduled fees reaches $246 for the total family, we know that those people will be eligible for 100 per cent rebate of the medical benefits scheduled fee for whatever medical services they need. That is a very good backstop for those people who may now have to find the $3.50 extra if they are patient billed, and $2.50 extra if they are bulkbilled and non-cardholders. Those people will have that fallback position.

The principles of Medicare remain. I refer to the principles of making sure that nobody is denied access to the doctor because of cost. It has been argued by Dr Bob Woods in the House of Representatives that $3.50 is not much money. I disagree with him. An outlay of $3.50 depends very much on what percentage it comprises of one's total income. For people on a low income that is a lot of money. It may be argued that it is not much for one person, but it certainly is for families with children who may find they have three or four lots of payments of $3.50 to find when they visit the doctor. That is precisely the sort of thing that I will be looking for when monitoring and it is what the Government will be looking for to ensure that those people who previously did not have to find that money and who will now have to do so are not disadvantaged. We will be looking to see that such people will not be disadvantaged.

Also, I will be interested to see exactly what happens to the general practitioner clinics, be they entrepreneurial or not. I am not at all sure that we know at this stage what an entrepreneurial clinic is. Again, I think that is probably something that is taxing the minds not only of the Government but also of members of the medical profession. There is considerable concern that no clinic should get into the habit of practising less than quality care. The clinics have shown what it is like to have 24-hour care. A lot of folk left their general practitioners over a number of years because there was no after hours care or service. Perhaps sometimes there was a locum service, but many people got used to going to the outpatient or casualty section of public hospitals where they knew they would find treatment if they were sick in the middle of the night.

The 24-hour clinics have provided that service in the suburbs, certainly out of the hospitals, and it is quite clear that consumers like it. That is precisely what those clinics have been teaching the medical profession. I know that the quality of care provided in those clinics is challenging the profession. It is very interested and very busy in looking at further definitions of what constitutes quality care. This will not be defined for the profession by the Government. It is something that the Government will be pleased to have defined for it by the profession. In particular, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners is understood to have that role.

The agreed position of the Senate Select Committee's report on vocational registration was that the College of General Practitioners appropriately set standards of care for general practice. The Government in its response accepted that. I do not believe there is any doubt about the profession having the principal responsibility of defining standards of care. The Government will be negotiating with the profession exactly what practice grants will mean. I would say that such grants probably would differ from one practice to another. It would depend on whether one were a solo general practitioner or part of a large group practice. It would also depend on whether one were providing general practice as part of a community health centre or as part of a freestanding general practice clinic. In rural Australia it would certainly depend on whether one had an agreement between a number of doctors practising solo. Again, that would put a different character on what a practice grant might be.

These are the sorts of things to which I understood the Minister was referring when he answered questions the other day. I am sorry that Senator Walters seems to be unable to understand those differences. I have no trouble at all in understanding what the Minister was referring to. The profession is certain that it will have the say in how quality medical practice is defined, and the Government does not disagree with that. The Government will negotiate with the profession as to how general practice is best paid for, taking account of the Government's proper concern that no person in this country is denied access to that good quality care by the way in which it is paid for. Accreditation of general practice is clearly within the realm of the profession in terms of definition.

In summary, the legislation acknowledges that it is time to look at significant redefinitions and restructuring of general practice. It is recognised by both the profession and the Government that there is an oversupply of doctors. It is recognised by the Government, and to a large extent by the profession, that the principal problem of increasing costs under Medicare in the general practice area lies in the oversupply of doctors, associated with overservicing. In grave doubt is whether the demand effect has led to the increase in costs but, to put the matter most kindly, I suppose it can be said that the jury is out on the effect or size of the demand effect. There is agreement that the question of oversupply of doctors must be addressed. Indeed, the Government has signalled its intent to address it, and the profession has agreed that it will be talking to government on this issue.

It is also important that we maintain standards of care. To this point general practice care and health care across the country, apart from pockets of the population, are very good. Australia has a standard of health care to be proud of, but there are areas which to me are a matter of grave concern. For example, the standard of health among Aboriginal communities is very much less than the average for all Australians. That aside, we have a good standard quality of care. We need to appreciate the importance of maintaining that standard and should address ways in which it can be improved. I refer in particular to the opportunity for government and the profession to negotiate the restructuring of general practice and build into it the continuation, maintenance and improvement of quality care. This will be to the benefit of all Australians and must be at an affordable price to both individuals and the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
