SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past half an hour, minus the last three minutes, I have witnessed some of the most lunatic contributions I have ever heard with regard to the issue of health. I just find that Senator Crowley's contribution has been incredible. For Senator Crowley, in her position as chair of the working party, or whatever it is called—the committee that revolted against the Cabinet decision and the Budget decision on Medicare—to have to come along to the Senate Standing Committee last Friday to ask the questions that she did, I find quite extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: It was quite clear from that exercise that Senator Crowley had not been given the information which, I believe, she should have been. She was in the position of not only being a member of the Caucus but also of being chair of that committee. Given that the Government treated her and the whole of her committee in such a way, is it any wonder that we are now dealing with this legislation that has caused so much dissent and anguish within the Hawke Labor Government? It is simply a bandaid approach to health by this Government that has a record that is nothing short of appalling.

The coalition is not opposing this legislation that is attempting to contain costs and that provides implicit, grudging recognition that the free consultations promised by Medicare lead to overuse and higher costs. We need to go back to when Medicare was first brought in. Medicare was promised to be a universal, self-financing health system. Quite clearly, it is anything but. It is not universal—I will come back with more examples or that later—and it is certainly far from self-financing, the result of which we are seeing today in this legislation.

It does not alter the fact that I deplore the lack of consultation that, yet again, has been characteristic of this Government's dealings with the medical profession and with health care professionals generally. As my colleague Senator Walters quite eloquently said earlier, the Government did learn a very valuable lesson from the pathologists in that it found that it cannot ride roughshod over the medical profession and the professionals within that profession. They know their law best; they know their services best; they are the people at the coalface; they are the ones dealing with the patients; not this out of touch Government that believes that it can just legislate for a profession and have no concern whatsoever about the consequences for the patients.

It is typical of this Labor Government to have promised in 1989 to enhance the status of general practice and now to spring this measure on the practice in a manner that suggests a complete lack of concern, without tackling the deeper problems of Medicare. Whenever, by direct statement or implication, this Government tries to blame general practitioners for the cost of medical services, it should be noted that in Western Australia 71 per cent of medical services were charged at the schedule fee that, over the last eight years, has risen at half the rate of average weekly earnings. Does this Government know or care? No, it does not. It keeps on saying that it is the greedy doctors who need to have their earning ability clipped. The Government does not care whether it is accurate to say that the doctors, according to the Government's vague figures, are earning too much money and the Government is bearing the brunt of that. Quite untrue.

The preferred style of consultation with the medical profession by the Government was so aptly demonstrated on 4 September when the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) threatened to allow unrestricted entry of foreign doctors if the AMA proved obdurate over changes to general practice. In other words, the Government said, `If you, the AMA, block what we want to do, we will let more and more foreign doctors in'. It does not, for one moment, look at the real problems of how we get more doctors into country areas. The Government just says, `We will bring in more foreign doctors; we will send them out to the country areas'. The very real problem of oversupply and maldistribution of general practitioners suddenly becomes a very convenient bludgeon against the AMA, although the problem was squarely diagnosed in 1988 by the Doherty Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce pointing to the wastage and lowering of skills that result when too many doctors enter general practice.

What has the Government done? It has simply ignored the recommendations. Again, it has done nothing to attempt to get more doctors into the country areas. It has just used this crude threat of bringing in more foreign doctors. For years the coalition has stated that if people who are not pensioners or welfare beneficiaries are able to obtain free medical treatment through bulkbilling, inevitably there will be some overuse of the system. That is exactly what we have seen.

A recent submission before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs noted that 23 years ago the Granville area of western Sydney was serviced by eight doctors. Now there are 20, yet the population is the same. I really cannot think of a more succinct illustration as to the effect of unrestricted bulkbilling in raising overall costs and encouraging the maldistribution of general practitioners. This is a truth that this Government has tried desperately to evade. Even now, the idol of bulkbilling must be placated by the fact that the co-payment is to be $2.50 rather than $3.50, wiping off between $70m and $90m in anticipated savings.

What is happening to that figure? No-one has been told. The Government will not tell anybody. We just do not know where that money is going. But there had to be this compromise to keep the leadership of the Labor Party firmly—or not so firmly—in the grasp of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Therefore, the leadership issue has become far more important than this huge re-jigging of the Budget. No-one knows where it will end and, more importantly, the Government will not tell us.

Maybe we will hear about something in some vague statement the Prime Minister will make later this week; but I doubt it. He has already made a statement in March this year, we had a Budget in August, and now he is being forced to make another statement. The best thing he could do would be to make a statement to the people of Australia that he is going to quit. Here we have the wiping off of between $70m and $90m with no explanation. By such means is a measure of peace brought to the confederation of warring tribes that constitute the Labor Party Caucus. As always, logic and good government have taken very much a back seat to leadership battles between Mr Keating and Mr Hawke.

It remains to be seen whether the fears of the ideological supporters of bulkbilling will be realised and whether the administrative cost of a $2.50 co-payment will lead to numbers of doctors abandoning bulkbilling. I do not apologise for one moment for welcoming a reduction in this practice for patients who are presently being implicitly fed the damaging lie that health services come free. They do not and they cannot. There is simply no logical argument for imposing a price signal on pharmaceuticals, as was done last year, and neglecting to subject medical services to the same discipline. It might be a bit much to expect the Hawke Labor Government to forgo the campaigns of fear and misrepresentation with regard to the coalition approach to health, now that it is forced to take some tentative steps toward reality.

I must emphasise that yet again this Labor Government lacks the courage and the unity to tackle the real health issues. Australia continues with the irritant and farce of the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy, which will raise $2.6 billion in 1991-92—less than 20 per cent of its health expenditure of $13.7 billion. That figure really does demonstrate the farce of the statements and the impression this Government tries to convey to the people of Australia that Medicare is free and that Medicare is self-financing. What rubbish. The levy is bringing in less than 20 per cent of the total cost of health.

Those people who are privately insured also have the misfortune of paying four times for their health cover. Even the people who are not privately insured are invariably paying three times: that is, via the levy; via increased general taxation; and, in many cases, through gap payments. Yet those who are privately insured have the fourth additional cost of private health insurance. But does this Government care? No, it keeps on going out there and trying to pretend that Medicare is free and self-financing. The Prime Minister has been very coy in refusing to rule out a rise in the Medicare levy. If this occurs—and a figure of 2.2 per cent has already been floated by Caucus and agreed to by such organisations as the Doctors Reform Society—we can remain confident that it will still not be an honest levy that actually pays for health care, but will be nothing more than a disguised tax hike. That is all it is at the moment; it is just added to tax. It is just that constant bracket creep that goes on.

There are no incentives for private insurance. Yet in 1990, when the Medicare levy raised $2.4 billion, $2.7 billion of health care expenditure was made by the private health funds. More was paid by the private health funds than by Medicare. Once again, we see the hypocrisy of this Government, which treats private health insurance as a luxury, yet depends upon 44 per cent of Australians retaining it to prevent the collapse of the public hospital system. What would happen if those 44 per cent of Australians opted out of the private health insurance system tomorrow? The whole Medicare system would fall over and die in a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—We have had a most profound interjection from Senator Crowley, saying no, it would not. With the private health funds carrying 44 per cent and $2.7 billion in health expenditure a year, if that cost were suddenly transferred to Medicare—which cannot cope now; that is why we have the legislation before us tonight—how on earth could anyone say that it would not fall over dead? That is a most extraordinary statement. The $600m contributed by private health funds to public hospitals in 1990 amounts to another tax upon private health insurance. This Labor Government, through its ideological preoccupations and its sheer laziness, continues to tolerate a situation where 40 per cent of Australians with private insurance have incomes below average weekly earnings and 20 per cent have incomes below $160 per week. Yet they clearly feel that they cannot afford to rely upon Medicare for hospital treatment.

PARA.TAB: Who would blame them? The Prime Minister does not rely on Medicare for public hospital treatment. He goes elsewhere; he goes into a private hospital. Dr Lawrence, the Labor Premier of Western Australia, had to have a gallstone operation. Where did she go? To the Mount Hospital in Perth—a private hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public is not good enough for her.

—Senator Walters is quite right. Yet the Doctors Reform Society had the audacity to say to me the other day at the Senate Standing Committee hearing, `Yes, but when someone like Mr Holmes a Court needed help he went to a public hospital'. Sadly, we all know what happened to him.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the public hospitals cannot cope, and that is not a criticism of the public hospital system. This Government continues to do nothing about the fact that 25 per cent of Australians with incomes above $1,000 per week do not have private health insurance. Those people will lengthen the Medicare queues for those who have no alternative. Surely this is a strange idea of social justice. It is not social justice, and there is no point in trying to pretend that it is. This Labor Government will not face up to the fact that unless the slow decline in the percentage of Australians with private insurance is reversed, the entire health care system is on borrowed time.

Senator Crowley's saying that she would not fall over and drop dead tomorrow if the private health system were taken out, puts her squarely at odds with the Western Australian Minister for Health who knows full well that Western Australia is suffering. While, judging from Senator Crowley's demeanour, he is obviously not from the same faction, nonetheless, he has quite a good point. It is a likely development that co-payments for medical services will result in greater use of public hospital outpatient services, thereby compounding what is our most pressing health problem.

Western Australia is in a very sad state with regard to health—and with regard to everything else, for that matter. Western Australians become increasingly concerned when they learn that the Royal Perth Hospital, purely and simply to contain costs, must drastically reduce its services and suspend elective surgery every fourth Friday. The Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, to achieve cuts of $2.2m, is to abolish some services and restrict non-emergency surgery between 8.30 a.m. and 4.30 p.m. The Bentley Hospital may be forced to abolish 10 beds for elderly psychiatric patients to save $600,000.

A real cut of $6m in Western Australian public hospitals means that people do not get the medical treatment that they urgently need. It was reported on 1 September that an 80-year-old lady in Perth lost two toes through gangrene while awaiting admission to Royal Perth Hospital. In June, her general practitioner sought an emergency appointment with the vascular clinic, but one could not be made until 11 August. So an 80-year-old lady lost toes as a consequence of the lack of funding by this Government of the public hospital system. I note strongly the comments of the lady's GP, who did not blame Royal Perth Hospital, but stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The system's just got to change. We can't have the Federal Government saying everyone can be seen free.
That put the blame squarely where it belongs, and it is quite correct.

PARA.TAB: A measure of the pressure that Medicare has placed upon public hospitals is that, on 3 October, a memo from a medical services director of the Gairdner Hospital stated that the hospital had simply stopped taking new orthopaedic patients because of demand pressure; the situation would be reviewed in January. What happens between now and January? One may well ask what happens after January because the funding situation will not change. In effect, Medicare patients are even losing the right to be placed in a queue. They may have to resort to the law to obtain treatment for what is so often acute pain.

As I said before, I do not raise this matter to blame the hospitals so much as the Medicare system. The Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia has drawn exactly the same conclusion, stating that Medicare was in crisis. Yet Senator Crowley, in her speech earlier on, said, `The principles of Medicare remain'. If they do remain, they are pretty sick principles. Even Senator Crowley's own party colleagues in Western Australia disagree with her. The same Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia stated publicly on 6 September that the Medicare levy is misleading and that bureaucratic Federal health administration forces the States to carry the can for Medicare.

On 12 September, Mr Wilson supported the proposals of the Australian Private Hospitals Association that would, in effect, confine Medicare to those in need and oblige other Australians to take out private health cover with some taxation incentives. It is an interesting difference of opinion within the Labor Party itself. On the release of the national health strategy report, Mr Wilson was critical of the fact that the Government had not investigated the possibility of scrapping Medicare, requiring those on high incomes to take private insurance and offering them tax rebates.

Why does the Government not really get dinkum about the problems of health in Australia? Why does it not really start looking at the situation as it is and not necessarily just do what its ideological whims wish it to be? It must start looking—hopefully sooner, rather than later—to make the changes that are necessary. In effect, a State Labor Minister is rejecting the ideological premises of Medicare that have been so smugly and very blindly upheld by this Labor Government for far too long. It cannot go on pursuing these premises, leaving people unable even to join the end of the queue and just rotting. That is not good enough.

When people in Western Australia who have no money are told by the public hospitals system, `You have to go to a private hospital and you have to pay for it yourself', what is their choice? They have no money, they cannot do it and, more importantly, this Government does not care. Of course, we may only speculate as to when it may embrace reality on this subject.

I suppose that it is not much use asking this Government to do anything about the situation because certain elements within the Labor Party obviously will not allow change to happen. I only wish that some of them would get out into the real world—get out into the public hospitals—and talk to some of their constituents in Australia. They should talk to those who are in pain, those who need surgery—relatively minor, as well as major—who simply cannot get it. They should talk to those who are being told, `You pay, or else'. Quite frankly, the reality of the `or else' for them is a very serious choice. It is about time that this Government made some proper decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The health system in this country is in a chaotic mess. This attempt by the Government to tinker at the edges is too late, too little and, in my view, should be rejected. I am going to vote against this legislation, because I believe that it ought to be redrawn and redrafted so that we have before us a set of principles and measures which will be able to remedy the chaos that is now rampant in the health care system in Australia. At present there are queues in many public hospitals for treatments that I would regard—as, indeed, would the patients who are waiting for those treatments—as being essential. This Government's policy has resulted in far too much suffering in the extended suffering of people who are chronically ill.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 is to increase the difference between the Medicare rebate and the schedule fee, and to establish new safety net provisions in relation to the maximum amount paid by families in a year for the difference between the scheduled fee and benefits. The Bill does not tell us how it will reduce the queues.

As Senator Knowles said—and it is my view—the net result of the co-payment idea will be to increase the outpatient queues in public hospitals. I may be proven wrong, but I believe that that will be the end result of this measure. I am very concerned about the effect it will have on the struggling families who are paying their way. I am also concerned about the effect that it will have on aged people, superannuants—not only those who are chronically ill but also those who may require medical treatment up to and including the safety net limit.

First of all I will deal with those families who are in that bracket just above the FAS limit. Of course, FAS recipients are covered by this legislation but those above the FAS limit are not. It is these people who are getting it in the neck in every way from this Government. For example, the Hearing Services Bill, which we debated last night, covered FAS recipients. But families who are just above the FAS limit can absolutely whistle. This appears to me to be the attitude of the Government so far as these people are concerned. We are not talking about the wealthy people in this world. We are talking about electricians and tradesmen with a couple of kids—one-income families whose income is just above the FAS cut-off point. These are the people who are hurting.

I was driven to Parliament House this morning by one of our car drivers. These people are not in receipt of an enormous amount of money. My driver happened to be wearing a hearing aid which cost $1,000. He could not get any recompense for that; he had to pay for it up-front. It is essential for him to have the hearing aid. Sure, such an argument was advanced in yesterday's debate but this is just another example of the hard-heartedness of the Government in respect of those people.

This Government is relying on advice from its bureaucrats in this area. We all know that, increasingly, the economic rationalist philosophy is becoming dominant amongst those in the top bureaucratic positions in Canberra, many of whom belong to highly paid two-income families. We now have another example of that philosophy. In an attempt to somehow get a user-pays system into operation, the Government dreamt up this co-payment idea. In my view, it has done so without regard to the effect it will have on the type of family that I have just mentioned.

The Government would not know what it was like to attempt to make ends meet on one income. It would not know of the effect that the current recession is having on families where the mother has been forced, through economic circumstances, to go out and get part time work. Now, because of the recession, they are forced out of that part time work without receiving any compensation at all. Nevertheless, the Government is now imposing a co-payment on those people. I believe that is unfair and unjust.A similar situation exists with superannuants who have worked and struggled all their lives. Each week—either voluntarily or compulsorily—they have put money into a superannuation scheme. Those superannuants are now faced with having to make these payments.

It might be said by the Government that there is a safety net—an amount of $246. But people will have to pay out that $246 a year before becoming eligible. That is another impost on these families and on these superannuants. There is much more I could say about this Bill but I said at the outset that I would be speaking for only five minutes. I did not put my name on the list of speakers, so I will stick to that promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a long five minutes.

—My glasses need fixing. I conclude by saying that I will be voting against this Bill. I will not be doing so just to take something out on the Government, because that is not my nature. This Bill should be withdrawn, redrafted and brought back—I think the Government will find that it will have to do that in any case.

PARA.TAB: Let me make one final point. I am not oblivious to the fact that there is overservicing by a number of medical practitioners and people in the profession; that they are bleeding the system, bleeding the taxpayer. My view is that the people in the Health Insurance Commission know that the taxpayer is being bled by overservicing. The statistics are available. The Government should act on those statistics by giving the Health Insurance Commission more staff and the power to seek out instances of overservicing and then impose greater penalties. I appreciate that the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) goes to that question. But I do not think even that legislation goes far enough. A greater number of people should be involved in this investigatory process so that the taxpayers' money is safeguarded.

I assume that we are about to hear an announcement from the Treasurer (Mr Kerin). Under the Health Insurance Amendment Bill, the taxpayer, who is funding Medicare through the Medicare levy, will have to pay $3.50. I assume that we can expect tomorrow, once this Bill has been passed, an announcement by the Treasurer that the Medicare levy will come down, or am I again whistling in the wind?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. It has been a very exhaustive debate. I think the Senate, in its consideration of the substantial matters in the Estimates Committee, in the special committee held last Friday to deal with submissions from various organisations, and again tonight, has said just about everything that can be said about the merits of this proposal.

PARA.TAB: I think the debate got somewhat out of hand at times tonight. I was disappointed with Senator Knowles and what I took to be a gross invasion of privacy of those who have received hospital attention, particularly surgery, in a particular class of hospital. I do not think that should be made a matter of public comment. I think patients are entitled to their privacy, whatever their status in public life. In particular, I found incredible her linking of Robert Holmes a Court's admission to a public hospital and his tragic and untimely death. I think that was a most unfortunate passage in tonight's discussion. Apart from instances such as that, the debate has canvassed many of the issues which have previously been exhaustively dealt with by the Senate in its Estimates committee process and in the committee on Friday.

Quite clearly, the Government intends that the measures this legislation incorporates and enables are only part of a whole package that has been announced in the Budget. The Budget foreshadowed further regimes and schemes to encourage a reform of the way in which general practice is both delivered by medical practitioners in our society and approached by those who require this primary health care given by GPs in our social structure and according to the expectation of the community.

There is no doubt that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has taken very firm steps to remedy what he has perceived—I think quite correctly—as the growth in use of medical services per person in Australia. The measures being undertaken represent a very radical step in the evolution of Medicare in this country but have nevertheless been required by the increased use of medical services to which I have alluded.

It is also important to note in the consideration of this legislation—it is not directly dealt with in the legislation, but it has been commented on often—that consultations and discussions have already been undertaken in a preliminary way between the Government, the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. Following a meeting between the Minister and the presidents of those organisations, those meetings have got under way. I have been informed this evening that the meetings that were held on Friday afternoon—which were spoken about during Friday's committee hearing—led to the documents tabled by me in that committee meeting being slightly amended to meet concerns of the medical profession and to further accommodate its views.

Whilst the AMA and the RACGP have still to agree formally on the structure, officials are now satisfied with the stage that has been reached in setting up the process of consultation. It is my understanding that it is expected that the general practice consultative committee—the top level consultative group proposed—is planning to meet for the first time on 21 November. It seems that the process is getting under way. I expect that will be undertaken in good faith on all sides, and we can hope that the consultations will allow the matters that have been foreshadowed as part of the Budget package to be modified and refined in a way that enables their practical implementation amongst general practitioners in the Australian community.

It is also important to note the contribution made by Senator Harradine. He expressed a genuine concern about the effect of the co-payment on the finances of a household, a family, in Australia. I can only say again that the safety net proposals represent a substantial improvement in protection for families. As Senator Harradine will know, there is currently a requirement for payment of up to $246 per person; that is the safety net threshold for an individual at the moment. This legislative proposal would make that safety net threshold amount of $246 the same for families as for individuals.

I believe that where a family with one, two or three dependants is subjected to a sudden acute, serious illness or a series of illnesses or there is a chronic condition of one or several members, the fact that out of hospital private medical services can be obtained for a maximum of $246 a year—where its doctors charge the schedule fee or less—is a very considerable improvement on what would otherwise have been the family's situation. In fact, I am told that the change would reduce the maximum costs for out of hospital private medical services of a couple with two children from $984 to $246 a year where their doctors charge the schedule fee or less. I think there has been a genuine attempt by the Government to meet the concerns of families which Senator Harradine has quite properly outlined as a matter of concern to the chamber.

I believe that most matters which have been canvassed in the debate tonight have been exhaustively dealt with during the consideration of these matters in various forums of the Senate over the past couple of weeks. I do not believe that I can usefully add to the discussion. I simply commend to the Senate the Health Insurance Amendment Bill and the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2), which carry out several reforms. As Senator Harradine noted, they introduce a new penalty provision and a new set of referral powers to a Medicare participation review committee. It is believed that the operation of that committee will help to act as a deterrent to medical practitioners who render excessive services. I believe that the empowering of those committees and the penalties in relation to the participation of the medical practitioner in Medicare arrangements will have a substantial effect on the temptation to which a medical practitioner might otherwise succumb to render excessive medical services. I commend both Bills to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this Bill will give effect to the measures announced by the Government in the Industry Statement of 12 March 1991: "Building a Competitive Australia". The Bill will extend the existing wholesale sales tax exemptions to cover a wider range of business inputs for use by goods producers and certain other categories of persons.

Goods producers include those persons carrying on business in the primary production, mining and manufacturing sectors. Other persons that will become entitled to exemptions include research and development entities and cargo handlers at sea and international air ports.
Exemption will also be available for subcontractors to goods producers or to any of the other eligible persons.

These measures demonstrate the Government's commitment to reduce the costs incurred by Australia's goods producing sectors. Goods producers will be able to be more competitive in both domestic and international markets as a result.

The cost to revenue is estimated to be $445m in 1992-93, which will be the first full year of operation of the measures. The overall benefit to Australian business, allowing for the flow-on effects of reducing costs earlier in the production chain, is expected to be over $1 billion in that year.
New exemptions for goods producers
The Bill will extend sales tax exemption to a wider range of goods used in production-related activities such as:
research and development or engineering and technical design of goods or production processes
mine site rehabilitation
the transport of goods by rail, pipeline or conveyor between production premises, eligible storage facilities or exempt ports
storage, handling or dispatch of finished goods, raw materials, work in progress or business inputs
certain ancillary and supporting activities which ensure the efficiency of the production process. These include:
- training production staff
- accident prevention
- pollution control
- lighting or cleaning of production premises
- scheduling or costing of production.

The Bill will introduce a new general definition of primary production operations. This will place beyond doubt that exemption will be available for general purpose tools for use mainly in carrying out such operations.
Research and Development Entities

In addition to goods producers carrying out research and development, this Bill will also apply to certain R&D entities, such as those registered with the Industry Research and Development Board. These entities will be eligible for exemption or refunds of tax which has been paid on equipment or materials used for researching or developing new or improved Australian goods or production processes.
This will assist specialist R&D organisations, even where they are not working under contract to goods producers.
Use
All of the new exemptions will be subject to a main use test, i.e., goods will qualify for exemption where used more than 50% in one, or a combination of, eligible activities.
Sea cargo and international air cargo handlers

The Bill will provide new exemptions for goods used by persons operating storage or handling facilities for sea or international air cargo. These exemptions will also include ancillary or supporting activities carried out in relation to the cargo handling process.

This important new measure will reduce the operating costs of Australia's sea ports and international airports and the benefits will flow on to all goods for export. This will enhance the opportunities for Australia's exporters to be truly competitive in international markets.
Subcontractors

Subcontractors will now be entitled to exemption for a wider range of equipment or materials used in work carried out for goods producers. It will be a requirement that the goods producer (or other eligible person) would have been entitled to exemption had they used the equipment in the same circumstances.
This recognises that there is now a greater demand by goods producers for specialist contractors to carry out activities that traditionally have been performed by the producers themselves.
Removal of existing exclusions

Under the current sales tax law, certain goods are specifically excluded from the various exemptions applicable to agriculturalists, miners and manufacturers. The Bill will remove many of these restrictions, thereby extending exemption to the following classes of goods when used in qualifying circumstances:
lubricants
office furniture, equipment and consumables
general purpose road vehicles when used exclusively within or between contiguous production premises.
Transitional refunds

The Bill will allow for special refunds where stock on hand has been purchased inclusive of sales tax after 12 March 1991, and where those goods are used for the first time after the commencement of this Bill, in newly exempted activities. This important transitional provision recognises that goods producers should not be disadvantaged merely because they are holding tax paid stocks of goods which will be used for the first time in exempt circumstances after the legislation takes effect.
Commencement
The changes made by this Bill will apply to all taxable dealings that occur on or after the date of Royal Assent.
Financial impact
The net revenue cost of the proposed changes is estimated to be $240m for the 1991-92 part year, and $445m in 1992-93.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) 1991, which is being debated today, provides the legislative machinery for the implementation of a number of social security changes which were announced in the Budget. While I envisage that the family allowance assets test will dominate this debate, I would like to concentrate on two other provisions in this Bill which serve to highlight serious deficiencies in one particular area of this Government's social policy framework.

PARA.TAB: This Bill contains two provisions which are designed to benefit a group which is probably the most socially disadvantaged of any group in our society. The group to which I am referring are homeless young people. First, the Government proposes to extend eligibility for rent assistance to independent and homeless people under the age of 18. This proposal will affect under 18-year-olds who are in receipt of the independent rate of Jobsearch allowance, sickness allowance, disability support pension and special benefit.

As I said, homeless young people are probably the single most socially disadvantaged group in our community. Anyone with anything to do with these young people is repeatedly told how difficult it is to find accommodation with rising rents, especially in the city, and bonds which make it virtually impossible for them to find accommodation or to maintain permanent or semi-permanent accommodation.

These young people face the additional problem that the amount of suitable and accessible accommodation which is available in the inner suburbs of cities like Sydney and Melbourne is rapidly decreasing. It is impossible to overestimate the value of permanent or semi-permanent accommodation to independent young people. Shelter is one of the three fundamental needs. For homeless young people, it is infinitely more important. A home is a refuge from the pedlars, the pushers and the pimps who haunt our cities and cruelly take advantage of the desperate and down-and-out in our society.

Without a home, these young people are infinitely more susceptible to a variety of problems, including malnourishment, disease, sexual exploitation and physical mistreatment. For these reasons, the Government's proposal to extend rental assistance to people who are in receipt of the young homeless allowance is very much welcomed by the coalition. It is a long awaited initiative that the community workers who spend their lives looking after these kids have been advocating for years and years.

Secondly, this Bill will allow certain special beneficiaries who are under 16 years to be eligible for Jobsearch allowance and sickness allowance. Such people must be above the minimum school leaving age, must have an employment history and must not be living with or being supported by their parents. They must also fulfil the normal criteria for qualifying for Jobsearch allowance. This initiative will end the discriminatory situation in which independent job seekers aged under 16 remain ineligible for labour market assistance simply on the basis of their age.

The coalition contends that the decision to extend labour market assistance to independent young people aged under 16 is a sensible but long overdue step in the right direction. For a long time, it has been known that the average age of street kids has been growing progressively younger. Anyone with any knowledge of youth homelessness will tell us that early intervention is crucially important.

By placing these children on special benefit, rather than Jobsearch allowance, the Government has, in effect, been fostering a welfare mentality from the earliest age. By not aligning access to labour market programs with school leaving age, the Government is telling one of the most disadvantaged groups in our society that it is not fit for employment. While the Government deserves kudos for both these initiatives, as well as its improved administration of the young homeless allowance, its overall response to youth homelessness since Burdekin has been, at the very best, mediocre.

The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Brian Howe, who has been primarily responsible for the Federal Government's response to Burdekin, admitted in July 1991 that the Government has been `very, very fuzzy about what homelessness was really about and what the causes were'. Mr Howe claimed that there was no way of knowing whether the hundreds of millions of dollars spent since Burdekin had done anything to help. He stated:

I don't think we'd ever know if we got there because we weren't all too clear what the problems were at the beginning. It's rare to see a program started with an evaluation built into it, so how do we know whether we've got there.

SPEECH.PARA: We most certainly have not got there, in terms of solving youth homelessness. In fact, I believe that we have gone backwards.

PARA.TAB: Last June, the founder of the largest youth services program in Washington, DC, Ms Deborah Shore, visited Australia and she brought with her a grim warning. Ms Shore believes that Australian reports on youth homelessness reveal that we are experiencing the same trends as surfaced in the United States 15 years ago. She urged school administrators, government departments, business and community groups to tackle the problem now before it spirals out of control. She stated:

Australia is at a critical stage in relation to young homeless people. What is going on now in US schools is dreadful. Communities are becoming like armed camps, the drug situation is so out of control. The level of violence is such that parents are asking for all the help they can get.

SPEECH.PARA: And a word of advice from Ms Shore to crisis workers in Brisbane:

Don't wait and study your problems, look at our problems and use them to help solve yours. The very same things that are forcing kids on the street in the US are forcing kids on the street in Australia.

If recent media reports are to be believed, Ms Shore's prophecies need to be taken very seriously. I remind honourable senators that so often we have followed in the footsteps of the United States in a number of the social issues that it has had to address—the women's movement, grey power and other social issues. I can think of one very recently that was pointed out at a conference I attended in law, psychology and psychiatry, where a psychiatrist from New York who had been one of the people advocating de-institutionalisation was calling on Australians to be careful not to follow blindly in the path of the Americans because the numbers of homeless people in New York had been increased and added to by the people who had been moved out of institutions. We have another warning here from a person in America who has been experienced in this area—as I said, the founder of the largest youth service programs in Washington, DC—warning Australia that we are following again in the US footsteps and that we ought to take heed.

PARA.TAB: The reports that we have seen in the media indicate that in the three years since Burdekin there has been an increase in the number of young homeless people but a decrease in our ability as a society to cope with this problem. One of Australia's longest running and most successful charities for street kids, namely, the Open Family Foundation in Melbourne, is battling to stay afloat due to an increased demand for its services and inadequate government and corporate funds.

A Uniting Church report last month on homelessness in the inner eastern suburbs of Melbourne found that there has been a 26 per cent increase in the number of homeless since 1989. The Wesley Mission in Sydney found in May this year that there had been a 30 per cent increase in the number of street kids since 1989. This is not centuries ago, this is since 1989—a 30 per cent increase. The Uniting Church reports a 26 per cent increase in Melbourne and a 30 per cent increase in Sydney.

The State-wide report by the New South Wales Youth Accommodation Association last June found that only four in 10 homeless young people find beds each night. We can well think about where the other six out of every 10 spend their nights. These figures are not confined to Sydney and Melbourne. Similar stories are starting to come out of every State capital, the national capital here in Canberra and a number of regional centres such as Cairns, Wollongong and the Gold Coast.

However, these figures do not tell the whole tragic story. A large proportion of these street kids are drug addicts and alcoholics whose only means of supporting their addictions is by prostituting themselves. Only a naive fool would think or pretend that none of these kids are HIV positive or have contracted AIDS. One Kings Cross inhabitant who was recently interviewed by a journalist from the Sun-Herald summed up the situation quite succinctly when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you're hanging out for drugs and a `mug'—
and for the uninitiated in this Senate that means a client—
offers you the money for a `job'—
that means sex—
without a condom, then you go for the money. AIDS doesn't seem to come into it.

These young people cannot wait while the Government fiddles. So what approach should be taken to tackling the problem of youth homelessness? I believe very strongly that there are two overriding principles which the Government must recognise when it finally formulates a policy in this area. Neither principle is revolutionary. Both were very clearly spelt out by Commissioner Burdekin. They are, firstly, to look at the causation and, secondly, to implement early intervention.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain. First, it must be realised that for all the parties involved, including the Government, the best solution to the problem of youth homelessness involves preventing its occurrence in the first place. Put simply, we must all put greater emphasis on treating the causes rather than the symptoms of youth homelessness.

While I know that the responsible Ministers, Howe and Staples, accept the importance of this overriding principle, there is little evidence that their rhetoric is finding its way into government programs. The Government must clearly identify the underlying problems which cause youth homelessness. These include unemployment, financial and work related stresses and pressures, the lack of affordable housing, substance abuse, abuse and isolation from support services.

Far greater emphasis must be placed on preventative measures in the areas of family counselling, mediation in family disputes, the provision of cooling-off periods, temporary accommodation, respite care and reconciliation. It must also be realised that it is not good enough to simply provide family support services. Without effective accompanying communications, marketing and networking strategies, these services will remain inaccessible and under-utilised, if the potential clients do not know that they exist and are not informed.

For example, a large number of family disputes come to a head during the evening or on weekends. However, counselling services are, in the majority, unable to take account of this important factor. I do not believe that the Government should underestimate the detrimental effect that the absolute dearth of after hours assistance for families has had on family breakdowns.

The second overriding principle that policy-makers must recognise is that an effective solution to youth homelessness, both in terms of individual victims as well as the overall problem, is very reliant on early intervention. I believe that in the community there is general acceptance that homeless children cannot and should not be held responsible for their plight and that, as a caring and compassionate society, we have a responsibility to assist them, especially to lead meaningful lives.

However, to date there is little evidence that this Government, or any of the State governments for that matter, is willing to make the sort of full-blown policy commitment that is required to prevent us from following in the tragic footsteps of the United States. Back in 1988, Burdekin stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Effective action is urgently needed to address this problem. Such action cannot be half-hearted or poorly planned. Homeless children and young people are dying in some cases and suffering horrific abuses of their rights in many others. Homelessness itself is a denial of rights theoretically guaranteed to our children and young people by the Commonwealth. This Report must be the catalyst for a serious and sustained response if this nation is to consider itself civilised.

Three years later, it is not possible to say that either the Commonwealth or the States have undertaken a serious and sustained response to the Burdekin report. Nor has there been any coordinated approach to homelessness both between tiers of government as well as across the relevant portfolios such as social security, health, community services, education, family and criminal law and housing.

PARA.TAB: The Government's response to Burdekin can best be described as piecemeal, spasmodic and ineffectual. Burdekin concluded that there were between 20,000 and 25,000 homeless children and young people across Australia. The Government, and particularly the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), have not been able to give me an up-to-date estimate of the number of homeless people, young people in particular, in Australia. Given the effects of the current recession and the fact that youth unemployment is now nearly 30 per cent, it is reasonable to assume that youth homelessness has risen significantly since Burdekin.

I am the first to admit that the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and the youth supported accommodation program have increased the percentage of total public housing stock that is available to young homeless people. However, a number of State governments have been accused of not upholding their end of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement bargain. There are also constant reports that youth refuges either are being threatened with closure or are unable to cope with the demand for their services because of inadequate funding.

While the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Brian Howe, has paraded his national housing strategy as the most important housing review in Australia's history, it is telling that not one cent of the $3m being spent on this strategy will go to examining the housing needs of homeless young people. Mr Howe has reportedly told youth workers that the Government believes that it has dealt with young homelessness with the Burdekin report. So we have had a report and that seems to be enough. The fact that not one cent of the $815m better cities program has been allocated to youth homelessness confirms the low priority that this Government is giving to the plight of homeless young people.

In the health area, both the Commonwealth's national better health program and its health promotion program have purported to focus on health issues which affect homeless young people. In spite of these programs, a recent study by the National Health and Medical Research Council has found that the majority of homeless young people have serious health problems. Street workers also report that an increasing number of homeless young people suffer from mental and psychiatric disorders.

In the area of education, the Government's disadvantaged schools program caters for students in disadvantaged circumstances. However, this program has also been stymied by inadequate funding and poor coordination between the Commonwealth and the States. These problems are now so dire that a project which the Minister for Social Security claimed two months ago to be the most innovative he had seen is unable to achieve any government funding at all.

This uncoordinated and piecemeal approach to youth homelessness resulted in Brian Burdekin last May venting his frustration at the lack of an effective response to his report. Speaking at the launch of a report by the Salvation Army into youth homelessness in Victoria, Mr Burdekin stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There are some serious questions to ask ourselves in. . . the next couple of weeks in terms of where resources will go and what our priorities are and whether the most disadvantaged and vulnerable groups in our community are getting the sort of priority on the political agenda that they need to get if we are to genuinely consider ourselves a civilised and caring community.
Referring to the urgency of the problem, Mr Burdekin was adamant about the future cost of not paying immediate attention to the problem of youth homelessness. He said:
We will probably pay enormous costs in social security for the rest of the lives of these young people if we don't get off our backsides and start providing some decent programs.

Mr Burdekin is telling the Government that, even if it does not see youth homelessness as a priority for social justice reasons, it should at least recognise the financial price that will be paid in the future if this problem is not addressed now. It is a call to the Government that, instead of taking a short term approach, it should take a long term approach, both to the social consequences for these young people and the cost for future generations, if there is to be a huge proportion of young people dependent on the welfare system for the rest of their lives.

PARA.TAB: Certainly not all the blame rests with the Federal Government. As Commissioner Burdekin has stated, much of the problem lies with the fact that the Commonwealth funds which are designated for homeless young people are not being translated into practical on-the-ground programs by the States. Quite understandably then, youth housing and community workers across the country are very concerned that, as part of its reform of Commonwealth-State relations, the Government is proposing to untie $100m of SAAP grants that have previously been designated for homeless young people. I am well aware of these concerns, as is the Minister for Social Security who has had them expressed to him many times this year.

I conclude by saying that the Special Premiers Conference, if it goes ahead, will provide the Government with a great opportunity to show some leadership on the issue of homelessness and, in particular, youth homelessness. Last July, my hopes were enhanced by Minister Staples who emphasised the need for the development of national policies on the prevention of youth homelessness as part of the new federalism agenda. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We're kidding ourselves if we think we will solve homelessness by simply building more refuges. . . the root causes must be dealt with.

The next step is to improve local level coordination of service delivery through better planning, the provision of State level prevention services, related essential support services and longer term housing options.

For once, Minister Staples is right. The Government and the Parliament must look at the root causes of youth homelessness. It is high time that we had a national youth homelessness policy. We must set national objectives and a national framework for the solution to this problem. We must devise and implement coordinated, well-planned and adequately planned programs across all portfolios and at all three tiers of government. We must ensure that these are coordinated if we are to address this important issue. Above all, we must realise that these street kids, these young homeless people, cannot wait. They are crying out for us to act now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend my colleague Senator Patterson for her very careful and sympathetic analysis of the problems of youth homelessness. I also take the opportunity to thank her for her versatility in speaking at the stage at which she did during this debate. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), with which we are presently concerned, contains a large number of measures which in many respects go to enhance the social security system. But by far the most significant item is the introduction of an assets test for family allowances. Whilst this measure is in a sense a revenue collection measure, it has nevertheless focused attention on the merits of the family allowance in a way that I do not think has happened in recent years. That is quite unfortunate because, in many respects, the family allowance should not even be in the welfare system. If we believe in horizontal equity, then we ought to be regarding parents and families as having an entitlement to a payment of that sort without it having to be paid from the welfare budget.

PARA.TAB: We are all aware of the other great compensating virtue of it being paid through the welfare system rather than through the tax system, and that is that it enables the payments to be made to the principal carer rather than to the taxpayer. In that sense, of course, it provides a very great and valuable service, in most instances, to the mothers of young children. Therefore, on balance, it remains a very useful mechanism in the way that it is currently structured.

What this Government has done for families in relation to family allowances is very parsimonious indeed. The family allowance is still not fully indexed, and has remained in that condition ever since 1977-78 when it was introduced by the Fraser Government. Despite the fact that it was not indexed in the early years, in November 1982 there was a 50 per cent increase which restored the value of the family allowance to the average value at the date of its introduction. In other words, the Fraser Government is entitled to hold its head high as the Government that maintained indexation throughout its period in government from the date of introduction.

However, the Hawke Government has managed to see the value of the family allowance progressively reduced to the point where it has been estimated that in the order of $6.8 billion has been forgone. That amount of money has been taken from low and middle income families who would, in many respects, I think, value the family allowance above any other payment. That being the case, it is a matter of shame that not only has this Government been the one to cut back on the family allowance to such a significant extent but also its real concern in the context of this Bill will be to cut it back even further. That is a hard decision that it proposes to take and it is one that has caused a deal of anguish on this side, which is well understood. But, at the end of the day, I think we have made the right decision. We will support the initiative and I will elaborate on the details of it tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the implications of the `new federalism' on the Home and Community Care Program (HACC).
(1) With the proposed changes in the delivery and funding of programs under `new federalism', what guarantees are there that the HACC Program will be maintained at its present level of funding.
(2) What will be the implications on service delivery for those organisations presently funded under HACC.
(3) (a) How will the roles and responsibilities of the various tiers of government in service and program delivery under HACC be assigned; and (b) what criteria, if any, will be used.
(4) (a) How will national service delivery standards for the program be assured; and (b) how will national priorities for the program be determined and monitored.
(5) What mechanisms will be put in place to redress service delivery problems if they occur.
(6) What mechanisms will be put in place to ensure clear and direct accountability to client groups.
(7) How will the needs and interests of disadvantaged groups be protected.

(8) How does the department intend to (a) inform the community about proposals to alter HACC funding or service delivery changes; and (b) consult with relevant individuals and organisations prior to the implementation of any changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In the context of the Review of Intergovernmental Relations, the October Special Premiers' Conference directed that functional reviews of broad program areas be conducted. The Communique of that Conference also specified that the fundamental objective underlying any change arising from the process would be to improve the existing system for delivery of programs and services in the interests of citizens. The Home and Community Care (HACC) program was given a high priority for review.

At the July Special Premiers' Conference, leaders and representatives agreed that the Functional Review of Health and Aged Care should proceed with a view to integrating community care for the aged, post-acute and palliative care and younger people with disabilities into the broader functional areas to which they relate. It was further agreed that final decisions would be taken at the November Special Premiers' Conference in conjunction with decisions on roles and responsibilities in the areas of acute health and aged care. Therefore, while it is possible to outline the process and issues to be considered, it is not possible to anticipate the decisions of Heads of Government.

A number of policy reviews which relate to the HACC program have formed the basis for advice and recommendations to Heads of Government on the future directions of the HACC program. These reviews have included the Functional Reviews of Health and Aged Care and the Mid-Term Aged Care Review. In addition, Heads of Government have been informed on issues relating to health and aged care by Commonwealth and State Ministers with functional responsibility for health and aged care.
The responses below should be read in this context.

(1) Through the Review of Intergovernmental Relations, Heads of Government and Functional Ministers have been considering issues relating to program structure so that optimal outcomes for consumers can be achieved. Funding arrangements for individual programs such as HACC are not the focus of attention. Rather the focus is clearly on developing structural arrangements to ensure efficient and effective methods of service delivery which will improve outcomes for clients. Arrangements for the funding of the HACC program will not be determined until the November Special Premiers' Conference.

(2) In the Communique of the October 1990 Special Premiers' Conference, Heads of Government specified that in determining the functions of spheres of Government considerations would include the achievement of the most simple and cost-effective administrative arrangements possible. This was reiterated by Functional Ministers in September 1991 when they noted the need to ensure flexibility in service delivery arrangements, including sensitivity to local conditions and integration of services. Although the precise effect on service providers will not be determined until a final decision is taken in November, it is a central tenet of the Reform process that implications for service providers are taken into account.

(3) (a) The roles and responsibilities of the various tiers of Government will be determined by Heads of Government through the Special Premiers' Conference process and with input from the Functional Review of Health and Aged Care and the Mid-Term Aged Care Review.
(b) The Communique of the October Special Premiers' Conference discussed principles for assigning roles and responsibilities and noted that considerations should include:
the extent of any national interest and the scope and level of national objectives
the scope for diversity in approach between States including room for flexibility in delivery
unintended consequences and spillover effects that might arise from actions taken by any one State
achieving administrative arrangements that are as simple and as cost effective as possible
which level of government can achieve the most efficient system and the best outcome for clients
the best method of ensuring that services provided under related programs are coordinated, including at the local level, and provide the correct incentives for cost effective delivery
the need for clear and direct accountability to the electorate and client group
achieving effective evaluation and monitoring mechanisms at the least possible administrative cost to government and service providers.
(4) (a) and (b)

Functional Ministers, in the Communique of their September meeting, agreed that in the case of shared responsibility programs the Commonwealth would continue to have a role in 'strategic directions of policy, planning and evaluation of economic and equity issues'.

All documentation arising from the reform process has noted the primacy of the consumer in any change to program arrangements. A key means of achieving optimal outcomes for consumers is clearly through the establishment and monitoring of service standards.

(5) The commitment of Heads of Government and Functional Ministers to the objective of ensuring optimal consumer outcomes indicates that mechanisms to redress service delivery problems would be a feature of any revised program structures. One way of ensuring positive outcomes in this area is the establishment of appropriate accountability mechanisms and service standards.
(6) The criteria listed in the Communique of the October 1990 Special Premiers' Conference included the need for clear and direct accountability to the electorate and the client group.

Heads of Government, in agreeing that the Functional Review of Health and Aged Care proceed on the basis of aligning community care services for the aged, people with disabilities and post-acute and palliative care with the functional areas to which they relate, noted that such a structure could allow a better allocation of resources to meet the needs of these groups, avoiding unnecessary competition between types of recipients and cost shifting between programs. Improvements such as these would contribute to improved accountability to the target group.
(7) The focus of the reform process on ensuring optimal outcomes for consumers implies that the interests of disadvantaged groups would be a priority in revised program structures.

(8) In the Communique of the October 1990 Special Premiers' Conference, Heads of Government indicated that 'In considering the precise roles of the respective Commonwealth State and Local Governments it will be important to include proper consultation with the non government sector, which has strong interests in the service delivery area.' As a result there has been consultation with the community as part of the Functional Review of Health and Aged Care. The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) conducted consultations with peak community organisations in March 1991 prior to the deliberations of functional Ministers on directions for reform of the HACC Program.ACOSS also hosted two community consultations during August and September in the wider context of the Functional Review of Health and Aged Care. Key documents arising from the Review of Intergovernmental Relations, including the Communiques of both the October 1990 and the July 1991 Special Premiers'Conferences and that of the Functional Ministers' meeting in September, have been made publicly available to ensure that the community has access to information about the course of considerations to date. I anticipate that this process will continue as further decisions are made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What identifiable expenditure is currently provided to researchers and/or manufacturers to enhance the safety aspect of cars manufactured in Australia.
(2) What public documents give information about the allocation of such expenditure.
(3) Are Australian drivers and passengers disadvantaged by not having available to them certain safety features which are incorporated into European cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Transport and Communications under the Road Safety Research Program provides funding for research relevant to improving the safety standards of new cars sold in Australia (including both locally manufactured and overseas manufactured cars).
Relevant current research projects are:

Crash tests of new Australian-manufactured passenger cars under controlled conditions, to evaluate their performance against current United States standards, and to test the improvements that might be obtained by adding new safety devices.
Crash testing of individual component systems.
Continuation of a detailed study of real crashes involving injury to car occupants, to identify the nature and causes of injuries sustained, and identify possible design improvements.
Studies of the cost-effectiveness of a range of occupant protection options, and of car buyers' willingness to pay for such safety features.

(2) Information about the allocation of such expenditure can be obtained from the Department of Transport and Communications Annual Report; Automotive Industry Authority Annual Report 1988-89; and the Industry Research and Development Board Australia Annual Report 1987-88 and the forthcoming 1991-92 report respectively.
(3) The Australian motorist enjoys the benefit of vehicle design rules which are amongst the most stringent in the world.
Our rules are largely harmonised with international standards, most of which are those that apply in Europe.

We are also the only country, other than the United States of America, to mandate side impact protection. This has been in place since 1977. The Europeans are still finalising their regulation in this area.

The Government is determined that Australia will maintain its position at the forefront of international developments in vehicle safety. The Government is actively pursuing improvements in the level of protection offered by modern cars.
From the Australian point of view, the debate focuses on how to achieve the optimum protection against the background of our high seat belt wearing rates.
