TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the publication `The Global Challenge: Australian Manufacturing in the 1990s' which claims the potential to increase exports derived from further processing Australia's natural resources is unlikely due to the high cost of capital, high inflation, uncertainty in environmental review processes and lack of sufficient progress in micro-economic reform, does this report accurately reflect Australia's economic future; if so, what measures are in place to address these impediments to economic growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's natural resources include minerals, agricultural products and timber. Overall, the value of exports of these resources in a processed form is small compared to the total exports of unprocessed commodities. The Government is very conscious of the impediments to the further development of the processing industry in Australia and the need to address these both on a sector by sector basis and through general micro-economic reform. The state of industry development in the various sectors of resource processing is described below.

Australia's exports of processed minerals were valued at around $10 billion in 1989/90. There is significant export potential, particularly in the areas of aluminium, steel, mineral sands and magnesium. This is due in large part to our world class mineral deposits and mining industry, and strong R and D capabilities. However, the depressed state of the world mineral markets is limiting our opportunities for export.

There are substantial opportunities to expand exports of processed foods, particularly to the Asian region where demand for processed foods is growing rapidly and tastes are becoming increasingly westernised. A joint Industry-Government Working Group concluded that exports could expand from $2.2 billion in 1989/90 to $9 billion per year by the end of the decade.

Work is currently underway on the development of a Processed Food Industry Development Strategy. Currently the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is examining the impediments to the further development of this industry; input costs, labour, market access and R and D and technology. The strategy aims to build on Australia's competitive strengths in the efficient production of bulk agricultural commodities and enhance our processed food exports.

Australia currently exports nearly five million tonnes per annum of mature eucalypt woodchips valued at approximately $368 million. Two per cent of our local production of pulp and paper is exported, valued at $130 million.
The Government has developed the Pulp and Paper Industry Package which will promote the environmental and economic sustainability of the Australian industry.
Included in the package is a comprehensive set of environmental guidelines that have established the world's most stringent limits on pollution levels for new bleached eucalypt kraft pulp mills.
Also included in the package is a joint Federal, State and industry research program, to which the Commonwealth contributed $7.76 million, aimed at:
maintaining the capacity to research and monitor the environmental impact of kraft mills;
monitor international developments in improved kraft technologies and alternative technologies;
further reducing pollutants that may have adverse environmental effects;
achieving a 90 per cent reduction in organo-chlorines and in the longer term, developing of organo-chlorine free bleaching methods for eucalypt pulp.

In 1988/89 Australia produced some 900 kilotonnes of wool and after allowing for stockholding and yield factors 814 kt was available for processing. Only 13 per cent of this was processed in Australia before export.
In the cotton sector in the same year, 295 kilotonnes were produced, of which only 8 per cent underwent further processing domestically into yarns and fabrics.

The Government is seeking to promote the efficient processing in Australia of a greater percentage of natural raw materials such as wool, cotton, hides and skins. As part of the assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear sector, the TCF Development Authority administers the Incentives for International Competitiveness Program which incorporates assistance for raw materials processing with the highest priority given to export-oriented projects.

Since the release of `The Global Challenge: Australian Manufacturing in the 1990s' Report there have been a number of developments which address the factors identified in the report as being impediments to economic growth.
The relative cost of capital in Australia has been reduced as a consequence of:
the corporate tax rate being reduced to 39 per cent in 1988/89;
the Government's general economic policies which have resulted in falls in interest rates since the end of 1989;
the reduction in the inflation rate which is now at 3.4 per cent and forecast to slow further to 3 per cent in the 1991/92 Budget.
Significant progress has been made in micro-economic reform.

There have been major reforms implemented in the shipping and waterfront industries and tangible productivity improvements have been achieved which will benefit both importers and exporters. Road and rail transport initiatives are being pursued in close consultation with the State and Territory Governments, unions and industry. When implemented the reforms will place road and rail transport industries on a commercial footing, encouraging each to concentrate on the task to which it is best suited.

The energy generation and distribution industries also are being examined with the aim of improving their efficiency. Through the State Premiers' Conference an electricity National Grid Management Council for eastern and southern Australia will be established. The national grid will lower the costs of electricity generation and through lower electricity tariffs provide clear benefits for the cost structures of all Australian industry. It was noted in the Industries Commission's (IC) Report on Energy Generation and Distribution that the net effects of better production practices and pricing in electricity supply could, in 1989/90 values, expand national output by approximately $2 billion annually.

From 1 January 1993 mutual recognition of regulations and standards covering goods and occupations in each State will come into effect as a result of the Inter-governmental Agreement on Mutual Recognition under negotiation in the Special Premiers' Conference process.

A Building and Construction Industry Reform Strategy is to be implemented which will seek to raise the performance of that industry so that it will, inter alia, play a major role in national export growth and import substitution efforts. The Strategy will benefit the resource processing industries among others through reducing plant construction costs.
The combined effect of these developments will improve the competitiveness of industry in Australia through the reduction of costs that industry face.

Additionally, a high level examination of the effect of the taxation system upon business investment is underway. The review is being undertaken by a committee of officials from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Group is to report in the very near future.

In the March 12 Statement `Building a Competitive Australia', the Government announced that it would introduce changes to the depreciation provisions. Details were announced by the Treasurer on 26 September 1991. The Government also announced that it would also introduce changes to the wholesale sales tax provisions for goods used in the range of activities carried out by manufacturers, miners and primary producers.

Additionally, the Government has decided to reduce the input costs to industry by removing the import duties on some capital equipment. Specifically, action will be taken to remove the duties on minerals processing equipment not made in Australia.
The Government is aware of the uncertainty being felt in some quarters with the environmental review process and has implemented a number of initiatives to address these concerns.

Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, industry, union and conservation representatives have been co-operating in the Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) process through nine working groups based on different industry sectors. This process will establish a framework for moving industry sectors (including the resources sector) towards long-term sustainability. It should provide the basis on which economic and environmental issues can be reconciled in the national interest. The Government will shortly be considering the working groups' reports. Several of the groups, including those on Mining, Manufacturing, Forest Use and Tourism have looked specifically at such measures as the reform of environmental impact assessments.

As a further initiative towards resolving current uncertainties, Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments as well as representatives of Local Government have agreed to develop and conclude an Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment to provide among other things greater certainty of Government and business decision making. A draft of this Agreement is expected to be considered by the Special Premiers' Conference in November.

The Resources Assessment Commission was established by the Government in 1989 for the express purpose of providing it with independent, impartial and comprehensive advice on the use of Australia's resources. In conducting its inquiries, the Commission considers the range of scientific, social and economic aspects of a resource use issue to improve the way resource questions are analysed and resolved.

The Government is in the process of establishing an Environment Protection Agency (EPA) and has provided funds for this purpose in 1991/92. The EPA will play an important role in integrating environmental and economic considerations in decision making and should improve the Commonwealth's capacity to find long-term solutions to environmental issues.

The Government is presently laying the right foundation for proper consideration of environmental issues and their impact on development decisions. The frustration and confusion being felt by interested parties should be alleviated by the completion of current processes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked Mr President, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the remuneration for members of Senate committees:
(1) Is the amount payable to Senate committee members a proper reflection of the work involved.
(2) Are committee chairmen entitled to any benefits not available to deputy chairmen or individual committee members; if so, what is the rationale for those payments.
(3) Are all committee chairmen paid the same remuneration; if not, what is the rationale for any differences.
(4) Is the extra work, outside of scheduled hearings and meetings, that is undertaken by committee chairmen adequately compensated.

(5) Can a list of travelling allowance payments made to chairmen of all Senate committees and any Joint committees be provided, showing which committee, travel allowance payments by date and place, and the dates and places of public and private meetings for each committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) With the exception of Senate committee chairs, members of committees as such receive no special remuneration. Senate committee chairs receive additional remuneration determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. All Senators who are committee members are entitled to travelling allowance for each overnight stay away from their home base when that stay is occasioned primarily by a meeting of, or travel to or from a meeting of, a parliamentary committee of which the Senator is a member. (Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 34/1990, paragraph 6(b)). All Senators who are chairs of committees are also entitled to travelling allowance for each overnight stay away from their home base when travelling on committee business as distinct from attending committee meetings. (Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 34/1990, paragraph 16). These entitlements to remuneration and travelling allowance are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal which reviews and varies them from time to time. It is a matter of judgement whether the current determinations properly reflect the level of work performed by committee chairs and members.

(2) As noted above, Senate committee chairs are entitled to additional remuneration, and to travelling allowance for each overnight stay away from home when travelling on committee business. Other committee members, including deputy chairs, are not so entitled. These entitlements are the subject of determinations by the Remuneration Tribunal and are intended to remunerate and compensate committee chairs for their activities and responsibilities as chairs which exceed those of other members of committees.

(3) Committee chairs receive differing rates of remuneration. The chairs of standing committees receive less remuneration than the chairs of certain joint committees, but more than the chairs of select, privileges or legislative scrutiny committees. The levels of remuneration are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. I am not aware of the rationale for the differing rates of remuneration.

(4) The level of additional remuneration and additional allowances for committee chairs is set by the Remuneration Tribunal. Chairs of committees are, to a greater extent than other committee members, involved in planning and managing committee inquiries and considering papers, reports and correspondence. They are also called upon to address seminars and conferences on the work of their committees. It is a matter of judgement whether the determined levels provide adequate compensation for any extra work performed by chairs outside of scheduled hearings and meetings.

(5) I have attached to this answer documents which set out, for Senate committees and the joint committees chaired by Senators, the dates and places of public and private meetings, the dates of travel by chairs occasioning payments of travelling allowance in respect of those meetings and other committee business, and details of the payments made consequent on those meetings and that business. Since the material is too voluminous to be incorporated in Hansard with this answer, I will table it in the Senate. I propose to table this material each year since I consider that it should be publicly available in the same way as many other details of parliamentarians' remuneration and allowances are now made public at the end of each financial year.
